reviews.review: Beautiful garden, worth seeing (if you are already in the neighborhood). I enjoyed the garden on a beautiful spring day (early November), and it was worth the visit: It's particularly fun to see this little oasis looking toward the high-risers. It's not a "must-see" attraction, but worth going there if you are closeby.

Disappointed. The garden is very small and quite noisy being in a very busy junction. The bus stand is very close by and as the buses don't switch off their engines while waiting for their turn to leave it is quite polluted. It is well kept. Restaurant very overpriced.Not a pity as there are so many options to eat well in Buenos Aires.
Beautiful Gardens. If you are looking for a place to walk around in Buenos Aires and relax it is worth it to come to the Japanese Gardens

Beautiful garden. The place offers a beautiful Japanese garden that is open during the day.The restaurant operates for lunch and dinner. they offer very good Sushi and other Japanese dishes in a very relaxed atmosphere

Good example of a Japanese garden. It's very well manicured, superbly laid out, and has a couple of eating places. Be aware that weekends it is very crowded which means it has no tranquility that you'd usually expect from this type of garden.I imagine it's a lot quieter during the week.
Work and play. A gift to the city from Japan. An oasis within the concrete jungle, Worth a visit if you can, no more than two hours is needed. Have lunch in the pagoda
Japanese Garden Review BA. Nice garden for a quick getaway from the traffic and bustle. good walk for couples. Forgot the price, but was well presented for the acreage they had.
Watch the people. Very nice garden. Large, but mostly flat. Some nice examples of Japanese landscape techniques. Not enough places to enjoy the calm of a garden. A bit hectic.
Lovely. Really nice place to walk around on a sunny day. Giant coy fish included in the ponds! You can also write your wishes on the wishing tree.

Very nice garden . Placed in a very nice neighborhood, this garden is one of the must in Buenos Aires.Very clean, beautiful and perfect to hang out a couple of hours.If you get hungry, there's a Japanese restaurant inside and a couple of shops.

Beautiful Oasis. We visited the gardens during a mid-week afternoon. We found the garden very well maintained - similar to ones we visited a number of years ago in Tokyo and Kyoto. While boarded by busy streets, the gardens seem well isolated from the busy city. A wonderful display of plants and Koi fish. Depending on your interests, a visit will take approx. 1.5 to 3 hours. We enjoyed our visit very much and have recommended it to friends.

A very nice Japanese Garden in Buenos Aires -. I have been several times in Buenos Aires, but have never been at the Japanese Garden. This time - in springtime - I decided to go there as part of my Buenos Aires Bus tour - Stop 11 (Green) or 21 (Red). It's a great place to visit and stroll around for a couple hours.

Just another japanese garden. If you have ever seen a Japanese Garden, than this one will be just one more. The garden is very beautiful and well cared, but it is still no big deal. Yet, it's a little pricy.
A special garden. It is a Japan space in the middle of Buenos Aires.Everything is japan style with a very nice restaurant

Pleasant, but that's all. This a pleasant place to wander for an hour, but in the world of gardens, it's not a must-see or a show stopper. The best thing is ringing the big peace bell with a horizontal wooden pole.

AN OASIS IN THE MIDDLE OF THE CITY. You will find the peaceful Japanese Gardens, an oasis of calm and serenity in the middle of the crazy, busy, noisy city of Buenos Aires. The park itself is wonderfully kept and very pretty all year round, as the different plants, trees and bushes show their lovely colors at varying points in the calendar. Apparently the horticulture on show includes black pine trees, gingko, sakura, and of course, the ubiquitous bonsai trees, that will impress all budding gardeners and karate kids alike.In case you are wondering ‘why exactly are there Japanese gardens in Buenos Aires?‘, well, they were given as a ‘thank you’ to Argentina, by Japanese immigrants living in Buenos Aires, when they constructed this lovely five acre park in 1967.It is open from 10am to 6pm daily, year round, and costs a small fee to get in. To get there you can take a number of buses, including the 10, 37, 67, 102 or 130.
An accent of Japan in Buenos Aires. A large Japanese Garden within walking distance if you are a walker from the Eva Peron Museum, which should be on anyone's itinerary in Buenos Aires.

Peace in the center of the city!. This garden is beautiful, well kept and thoroughly enjoyable. we spent the afternoon just enjoying the loveliness of the garden, the fish and birds, and watching all of the other visitors doing the same.

Lovely spot!. These gardens exceeded my expectations - more "Japanese' than many of the Japanese gardens I've visited in Japan! Very well kept and some beautiful vistas - not surprised that we had to pay to get in as it must take some funds to keep it looking so good. Well worth a visit.
Nice place for lunch. When we have visiting guests, we always stop for lunch and walk the beautiful Japanese Garden, take a picture on the red bridge and enjoy the beautifully cared-for garden.

Nice and well maintained . Visited with my two kids and wife, we spend the whole morning there and enjoyed it for taking nice pictures. We've also tried the Japanese restaurant inside, which I recommend

The park is ok, the restaurant is good. This is a very small Japanese park compared with other around the world. Is cute and fun if you wanna buy a Bonsai or to have nice lunch. The park is not opened at night only the Restaurant that by the way has a very good Sushi. I recommend to make reservations and ask for the Tatami table that is fun to eat without shoes and like in Japan.  I'll be back for dinner!S

Nice place for a walk . I've been to this place 4 years ago and it keeps the nice garden as before. They use to have several japonese fish in the lake but it seems that they are gone...The ticket costs aprox 10 dolares.
Refund please!. Horrible!!Far too busy, water isn't clean and single file around the paths whilst waiting for people to take selfies.Really not worth the money

Beautiful & peaceful place. Really well preserved, beautiful! We had lunch at the restaurant which is inside the garden (really good sushis) and then had a walk in the garden. It's not that big but really beautiful!

Unexpected and wonderful. Absolutely lovely place. I was very unfortunate to go right before lunch, so I was starving and had to rush through it. But I hope to go back someday so I can just spend the afternoon and enjoy the extreme calmness all around the park.

Not the best. The entrance fee is about $5 (70 pesos), and there's honestly not a ton to do. We went to the restaurant, which was a little overpriced and not the best food. They do have koi in the pond, but the pond was super murky. We walked around for a while and then left. There is a cool plant shop, which we would have loved to shop at if we weren't traveling back home overseas.

Very well kept gardens. A bit of Japan in Argentina. The gardens are really well kept and appear to be very popular as it was packed when we went. It's a bit of peace and quiet in the middle of bustling avenues in Palermo. The entrance is 70 pesos (could be cheaper in my opinion). If you don't fancy going in, you can kind of see quite a bit of it over the fence on the north side.

Pretty but didn't feel very authentic. After visiting amazing gardens in Japan, this garden felt as if it had some aspects of zen style but not fully Japanese. It was still a pretty garden where you can take some lovely pictures. But if you have been to Japan then this may not be the real deal for you.
Great place to walk theough. Nice gardens with lots of flowers. We walked through it in less than 45 minutes. It's a good stop on your sightseeing walk.

Beautiful and enjoyable gardens. This is a beautiful place to go to, is an escape in the middle of the city, we were transported to Japan for a little. I highly recommend the place for a nature and landscape lover, some days the entrance is free for Argentinian residents.
The flowers, trees, landscape and Japanese environment is impecable, they sell food and plants inside.
Enjoyable experience. Beautifully laid out colourful gardens, good value for money, but does get exceedingly busy. May be worth while visiting shortly after opening time.

very pleasant place. The Japanese garden in Buenos Aires is the largest outside of Japan and it offers the genuine view and atmosphere of a Japanese garden. It has a splendid location in Palermo district and the high residential buildings surrounding it create a nice skyline.
I definitely advice to visit it.

Beautiful grounds with cultural exhibits too. The japanese gardens in palermo is a great place to visit on a nice day. It is a large garden compared to other japanese gardens i have visited on my travels. Great place for kids as an outdoor activity with ponds filled with hungry koi that kids can feed.

Very pleasant, worth a visit and the cover charge. 70 pesos gets you in for a pleasant stroll and some nice photo ops. You're a long way from Japan, but you can fake it in pictures ;).
I enjoyed this place all three times I visitied.

Great place to take timeout. Great Japanese gardens provide a level of calmness, this is one such garden. Beautifully presented and maintained with only slight awareness to the city noises. Not expensive and if in the area great place to relax before you scramble of to your next tourist destination
A nice place relax. People kept telling me to come here, it did not disappoint me. It was a great place to spend relaxing for a few hours.

Very nice even just to walk around. This attraction in a very central location in Buenos Aires is a calm place all over the year. Only busy when something special is going on as fairs or spring and summer weekends.It is a good spot for families with children as there are gold fishes that they can feed and beautiful bridges and gardens to go around.For sushi lovers there is also a Japanese restaurant inside the park.
Great for pics. Super cute, great activity for a sunny day, where you can take several great pictures and just hang there, with the zen energy.

Lovely but.... I spent a couple of hours here on a wet and cloudy day. Despite this, it was a pretty scene, although slightly marred by some high rise buildings in some views. I paid 70pesos to get in. If you've been to other Japanese gardens, I'd say skip this. There are lots of lovely parks in the area that are just as relaxing.

Dinner- Sushi. Best sushi in town. Expensive but very good. Great service.
Location is nice and the gardens are beautiful. It is totally worth it.

Don't compare to the real thing, but its lovely on it own. Slightly biased as I have seen/ experienced real Japanese Gardens in Japan. It is a very nice place to take a stroll around, has a cute little shop selling Japanese goods. There are koi in the pond but it is very much over run by green algae.

Exquisite Japanese Gardens in Heart of Buenos Aires. Lovely afternoon spent in these Japanese Gardens. The waterfalls and fish ponds are so spectacular and calming. Lovely landscaping and well maintained grounds. U almost forget u are in the center of a noisy busy city. U can find a quiet Corner here as well. There is a lovely cafe for afternoon tea, lunch or dinner. But check the times as they close at around 5 or 6 and then re open for dinner. Cute little gift shop with Japanese knick knacks and souvenirs . 70 pesos to enter so not a free attraction. The azaleas were in full bloom and absolutely gorgeous. They also have cherry blossom trees. But I missed those blooms. Highly recommend spending some time here.
Vi Sa. Very beautiful and refreshing place. If you are romantically set is for you. Fantastic landscaped. This is the place.

Usual Japanese garden . This is a standard Japanese garden, hasn't stood out from other Japanese gardens I've seen, but it's a nice wander regardless. Japanese gardens are always beautiful and this one is too. Don't travel to see it, but if you're in the area and have 30 minutes it's worth a look.

Lovely Concept and Outdoor Space. We liked the Garden and all the information about Japanese culture it offered. We were there on "Dia de los NInos" (Kids day) Aug 21st and they had a beautiful fire ceremony to burn small wood plaques w your personal writing of things that no longer serve you or are negative. I loved the concept and was only disappointed that when we asked for a plaque for our daughter, they said, Kids could not have one to participate. I am not sure if there was a reason culturally or if it was something else. I felt it would have been a beautiful chance to explain to kids to let go of negative things (even little ones can learn about being more mindful and positie - not just adults). It was also very crowded and some areas w bonsai trees we wanted to see closed or blocked off. Otherwise, a lovely place to visit and relax, walk, meditate.

Beuatiful and Queit. The Japanese Gardens are remarkebly queit given its location. It is a nice place to sit walk around and take a break from the often busy Buenos Aires streets. If this is close by, it is certainly worth a visit.

Decent Japanese Garden. We visited in late winter/early spring. The garden was well attended to and is probably really lovely in the summer. It was a bit noisy as it is bordered by a busy road. It was also inexpensive so it's nice to drop in if you're nearby. It only cost us about $5 per person (70 Argentinian pesos).
Pretty place for a break. Very pretty and reasonably priced, although small. Very nice and scenic place for a rest during a busy day sight seeing in BA.
Nice break.. This garden is ideal to take a few minutes out if the day. Suggest late afternoon not in the full sun. The garden is superbly manicured.
Very lovely and relaxing. Considering this garden close to main roads, it is a calming place. Also features an indoor exhibition area - we saw beautiful bonsai trees.

Cool but not essential.. It's a Japanese garden. Go if you've never seen one or you want some green or silent time (and the spaces nearby aren't enough), but it's nothing essential for your visit to the city.

Beautiful place to get out of the hustle and bustle of the city!. What a hidden gem! This place is very beautiful. The garden is designed well and has been maintained well. You only need an hour or so to cover the grounds and get some photos. We went in the afternoon which seemed like a great time to go as there weren't too many people. It cost 70 pesos to get in which is reasonable. A really nice place for a walk.

Amazing restaurant!. Go early and avoid the crowds. I visited on a local holiday and this place gets packed. The garden is small, but really beautiful. Stay for lunch at the restaurant. Truly, it was some of the best sushi I've had!

Nice 2-3 hour attraction. Great picturesque park if you are on that side of time. We stopped in for an hour or two. its inexpensive, and nice if you want to space out with other tourist attractions that require more rigour and walking. not much around there though, so you cant club it with other stuff. dont be too upset if you miss it.

Very nice. This is a lovely little park. We enjoyed it. They have a crepe stand that makes the most delicious crepes with multiple fillings such as salmon, chicken, veggies, pizza. The best one was the banana and chocolate crepe! The garden is pretty and well maintained and has the typical Japanese elements.

Very relaxing. It was like a trip to Japan, in Argentina lol. Everything is traditionally Japanese. It was really relaxing with the trees, birds and koi fish. It was fun to fed the fishes. There was also a Japanese shop that has allot of things of the culture of Japan and outside the shop was a wishing stand. That was very unique.
I loved everything about the Japanese Garden. I loved the Japanese Garden. I took lots of pictures to take back home in Florida and spent a great time with Fabri an Ezequiel here

Just for a short visit, don´t expect too much. It´s just a lake with orange fishes, a type of japanese garden around, but nothing else and some activities like origami or gardening. Don´t expect too much of this visit. Just as a complement of your visit to Palermo lakes and park.

you will love it!. It is a very beautiful place to visit. it is a pacific place in the middle of buenos aires. It is a good place to meet and spend a good time, for childrens there are not to much, it is better to go alone. A place to relax, relax.

the garden itself,with some negatives. As Japanese Gardens in the world go, I would rate this nicely. Surprisingly, most trees don't bloom until the middle of October which is the middle of April up in the Northern Hemisphere. Considering that this is an almost semitropical city, you'd think earlier, but maybe it works the other way around in warmer climates, things being relative.I like the small Japanese Garden with convenient small bridges and well-cropped shrubs and plants. There is a very good restaurant inside the main building where, on the second floor, classes are taught for a variety of Japanese oriented martial arts, etc. It is very very clean. What I dislike, as do any who have commented to me, is the overcrowding of the water area, loaded with goldfish, I believe, but severely overcrowded, as if no one knows what they are doing when it comes to space for fish. The rest is a nice experience in a beautiful area of the city and again, the restaurant, authentic, a bit expensive, is a treat.
Very peaceful and pretty. Very good for a short walk around, an oasis in the city, take a packed lunch and enjoy the day. Very nice for kids too.

Really pretty! . We visited the Japanese Gardens for a few hours, it's 70 pesos to enter, we found it much larger than we were expecting, it's much bigger than the gardens in Holland Park in London. We had a really lovely walk around, there are lots of nice features, bridges you can walk over, fountains and koi fish. The water was a little green so the visibility wasn't that great but it's a nice place to relax! There are a few places to buy food & snacks apart from the big restaurant!

Calm place. Not huge, and next to a busy road and some form of dog kennels with barking dogs, but some very well manicured grounds around lakes with some very large well looked after bonsai. Lovely bridges and plenty of picturesque vistas. A real oasis of calm in a bustling city. Also an interesting visitor centre with Japanese cultural exhibits and cafe. If you are in town for a few days and fancy a relaxing hour or so it is worth a visit to get away from it all.
Nice garden,. This was a nice garden with a large koi pond that you can see kois that were over a foot long. Theres a restaurant there but the japanese food was terrible. I would not go again

Defiinitely worth seeing. 70 pesos to get in, this is a wonderful Japanese garden, bigger than you might expect. Lots of water features, ornamental shrubs, bridges, bonsai exhibits, a Shinto peace bell which you can strike, benches to sit on. Very relaxing, and surprisingly popular with local young adults.

A small but beautiful Japanese garden and cultural exhibit.. We really enjoyed our trip to the Jardín Japonés in Palermo. The grounds were beautifully landscaped in that iconic Japanese style. There were amazing ponds, trees, koi and other interesting features. In addition, there is a main building with small library, restaurant and museum with items from Japan on display. This is a great place to spend an hour or two. My only regret is that we went there in winter - the grounds must be stunning in the summer.
Japanese Garden and Restaurant. Extremely beautiful place to visit (mostly in Spring).The restaurant is awsome, the quality of food excellent and the service is second to none.
Must see!. Awesome Japanese garden in the middle of Recoleta! Nice place to visit and relax watching the cherry trees.
Amazing. A very nice garden Jap style with a lake plentyfull of water plants and color fishes, alltogether in a perfent landscape. Also a japanesse restaurant 5 stars.

Beautiful!. To be honest, I am not sure how I ended up at a Japanese Garden in Argentina, but it was WELL WORTH IT.We first had lunch at the Japanese restaurant on site and it was amazing. We ordered sushi and it came out on the wooden boat. There were also tables I saw in the restaurant that were low to the ground and you could sit on pillows to eat...So COOL!The gardens were very peaceful and seemed to be popular because there were a bunch of people there. It never seemed overcrowded though!!It was fun to watch the fish and walk over the bridges and admire the scenery.There were restrooms and an interesting gift shop as well.Fun Fact: There was some sort of "Comic-Con" event going on at the gardens during our visit, and it was interesting to walk around and try to guess who the people were dressed as!

Gorgeous gardens. Absolutely loved this place. We went after arriving the same morning and dropping bags off etc. The idea was for just a relaxing afternoon but still do something. Very relaxing to just wander about. It was quite busy but still nice. I just wish I'd brought my proper camera. Entry is 70 pesos for non Argentinians which I can't fault (£3.60 roughly).

Lovely place. Must be visited.. Do not judge the place by thinking "why do the entrance costs 70 pesos?". Would go every week if I had the opportunity. Beautiful and peaceful place. Makes you feel like standing in oriental grounds. Tons of great pictures are guaranteed. Loved it!

Aussie in buenos aires. I am a landscape gardener i went to this tranquil garden with a friend ... very relaxing great atmospher ... not as many japanese plants as i thought more native to argentina which is to be expected .... still had a great day and rexommend it to travellers who nees a break from the rat race

Beautiful garden. The Japanese Garden is large, and a lovely visit. There are often special cultural events, and a restaurant as well as a food/snack area with really good crepes. You can buy fish food in the gift shop to feed the koi.

Beautiful place of peace and relaxation.. In the heart of Buenos Aires a beautiful place of beauty and peace in this garden you will find that relaxing time necessary to recharge your energy, surrounded by water, plants, fish, delightful bridges; also you find a tea house that serve delicious Japanese food noon.
70 pesos por entra?. Yes there is nice place to visit but entry fee is too high for value of them. but nice place take a foto. Under 12 years free to entry haha

Nice diversion and well laid out. Good activity for an hour if you are in Palmero for the the Museo Evita. Good to walk around and not very expensive to get in. Restaurant lookd good but we were not there at a meal time.

An oasis of beauty and serenity. . We walked the garden one morning. It was an oasis of beauty and just a lovely spot to visit. The sign going in tells you photos are not allowed without permission but when I asked the lady said they were allowed with a ticket. Nite that you cannot exit and renter with your ticket.

What a wonderful place!. An excellent atraction! This is my true opinion about this garden. It´s very well located, organized and clean. This place also provides a very nice experience, if you like to make contact with nature (flowers, trees and fishes), if you appreciate japanese culture, or both! You will need time to walk around the trees, cross the small red bridges and take pictures, as it is, in fact, a relaxing experience! The many pictures I took speak for me.
Great sushi in BA. The Japanese Garden is beautiful to have a walk during the day. It also has a japanese restaurant that you can visit even when the Garden is close.
Best enjoyed in the morning. Peaceful and relaxing way to start your morning before you deal with the noises of the city. Great for the entire family. This garden is worth visiting when in BA.

Go visit this oasis when you need some Zen. If you are into plants/ gardens / Asian or Japanese culture this authentic mini city garden can't be beat If you like none of the above but just want to break from touring the city or need a coffee and to get some calmness the Japanese Garden is still a very god spot to find your Zen. It is not well know nor an easy walk from most BA sights- but it is a under-appreciated jewel and a great oasis. You can get there I'm a taxi from most spots in just a few minutes and just a couple of pesos. Go there support and enjoy it!

A zen island in buzzing BA. Serene landscape, beautiful trees and flowers.... the fish ponds and more than anything else, the quiet atmosphere. Don't miss the exhibitions on the 1t floor of the building at the back of the garden.

A more authentic version of Epcot Japan. The gardens are a lovely way to spend a morning in BA before some of the other attractions open. Apparently, lots of other people felt the same- it was pretty busy, though not packed. The park is pretty small, and you won't feel like you're very secluded, but there is plenty to see. The music piped through speakers makes it feel a little like Disneyworld! I enjoyed a delicious pot of tea at the restaurant as well, and the bathrooms are convenient.

A little piece of Japan in Buenos Aires.. When in BA if you like delicate japanese gardens or have no other priorities you may pay a visit to this japanes garden. Apart from the garden itself there is a reasonable restaurant with japanese dishes, temporary exhibits and shops. Avoid it in week ends because of the crowds. Near to the Rosedal (rose garden worth visiting), the Planetarium and Alcorta Shoping center for a snack, best brands shopping or just a coffee in a rainy day all under one roof. Parking available.

Urban Oasis. The silience and order of the Japanese Garden was a welcome respite from the loud traffic on the major avenues nearby. A good place to stop for a brief rest and not far from the Museo Evita.
Very nice layout and clean. It was really nice but smaller than I expected. Very clean and organized. Nice layout. They charge a small amount of money for the entrance ticket.

One of the best paid visits of Buenos Aires!. A spectacular view of the Japanese architecture and nature. It is a very peaceful and enlightening place - the visit costs 70 pesos, which is a very fair price.
A little Oasis. Not very big but a nice Garden,Great to see how the Japanese intricatly tend to there gardens.Great places for a few photos
Beautiful. I really enjoyed this garden. It was very relaxing. With many water features to enjoy the grounds are spread out. So it doesn't feel too crowded. Beautiful pictures opportunities here.

Small Tokyo Garden. It is a tiny japanese garden excellent location, with fish in lagoon (carpas) which one can feed. Very nice walk, specially in a sunny day. There is a tea-house/restaurant which serves very good sushi.

Just ok.. Understanding that it's June, chilly outside and not the growing season in BA, I still felt it was worth taking a look at the famous garden.THE POSITIVES:- artfully mapped out with quaint bridges over streams.- large koi in the streams.- the trees and shrubs are well manicured.- several small snack kiosks selling chips, ice cream, drinks, etc.- one snack stop offered a small selection of gluten free treats! Delicious empanada! The attendant did not speak English at all, but was very kind and patient to try and communicate with me.- the banos where acceptably clean and stocked with toilet paper.THE NEGATIVES:- the park is bordered on 2 sides by major roadways. The traffic noise inside the park is VERY disappointing. - the koi are hard to see, as the water is very dark and murky.- I took my time, and tried to meander slowly - still I walked the entire park in less than 15 minutes. It is quite small, which is fine except they charge $70.00 pesos for entrance. Not a terribly large fee, but unsure of the value.- unfortunately there was a large group of boisterous students there at the time that I was. Adding their energy and volume to the road noise made for a rather unpleasant visit. No ones fault here, but the small space couldn't absorb the numbers.Overall it wasn't a waste of time, but if you are on the fence about visiting - then I would save the 70 pesos for something else.

The largest Japanese garden outside Japan. If you're looking for some calm in the city, this is a smart direction. It's certainly more packed in warmer seasons than colder, but it's a lovely site regardless of how many people are there. Every time I visit I see it as a Japanese theme park. It just seems to have a little bit of everything, including a restaurant (open during and after park hours), food stands, a gift shop, a gardening shop and more. And it's right off of Av Libertador.
Pretty, tranquil. Go ahead and see.. It was a nice experience. Very pretty and a nice thing to do out of the normal B.A. things going on in the city.

Fun in the sun but crowded and small. Pleasant enough but really pretty limited If it is a ice say go along and have tea in the park it has crammed a lot of different items in one space but still worth a look ,.
Only to spend time. Nice place to spend some time if you have not so much to do in BA. Also a little expensive and a little far from downton. Nothing special!
Pleasant walk in the afternoon. A pleasant walk after a busy day visiting the galleries. Quite a walk back to Recoleta, so take a cab
Very expensive ,. Nice landscape, but extremely expensive , on top of it you pay an entrance fee to go for lunch even if you dont visit the garden. They should reimburse people going for lunch.

A quiet place to visit and very well maintained.. Definitely a place to visit on a warm day, but great photo opportunities and a place to relax and enjoy the ambience of the gardens. Feed the koi and enjoy the flowers.

Better before. When the garden was run by the Japanese community, all was well. Clean, the water in the leake clean, the carp healthy and curious. The food in the restaurant, good japanese. When the local authorities took over, it fell to pieces. It has improved since, but locals enter froo but foreigners have to pay. I thoinkthis unfair. Go once, to get an idea of the place!

Well done and very beautiful . Saw this on my first day in the city as I was staying in Palermo soho. They have done an excellent job with crating authentic looking Japanese gardens. The entrance fee is steep for a city with free museums 70 pesos ($5) but worth it
Relaxing. Beautiful gardens in the middle of the city. Has a 100 Koi fish in a pond. Benches to sit and relax.
only ok. This garden was fine, not one of the better Japanese style gardens I have visited and quite expensive to get in.
Not worth the time and price. The park is not less beautiful then the garden and for free. If the weather is clowdy not worth going there.

Paradise in the middle of the city. It's a beautiful place to visit, but not during the weekends that it's full of people. It's a very good place to escape the craziness of the city. They have the best sushi restaurant in the city, but super expensive!!

Cute Garden. Nice and cute Japanese garden but nothing extraordinary.We went on a Sunday and every bench in the garden was taken over by local artists.which was nice but other visitors had no place to sit.Should make that artists bring their own chairs

a natural place to breathe and delight your eyes!. Excellent place to visit, japanes culture expressed in art, space, plants and flowers, fishes, stones, signs, music. All in a special habitat in middle of the huge Palermo parks. The Jardin includes a tipical restaurant. a nursery garden, a gift shop, teahouse, reading room and guided visits.

Relaxing walk. We wanted a relaxing walk but found the gardens packed with large loud childrens group. Running and throwing things un the large pond. Sad little fishies. There was a fish breeding program that was interesting. We have gone later, after the group if the ticket person told us.
A must see. Japanese Garden is a must see in Buenos Aires. The restaurant offers great food and the desserts are very much like in TOKYO. Super tasty!

Beautiful Garden!. We were really surprised to find such a large and gorgeous garden. There is a small entrance fee well worth it the visit. Very well cared with a couple of restaurants. It has a center lake with bridges and beautiful trees and flowers everywhere.

Charming Japanese garden in a neighborhood full of parks. Very nice place to visit with the kinds on an afternoon walk. You can also have lunch or enjoy a typical Japanese te at the restaurant. The kids love walking around the park with it charming Japanese bridges and feeding the fish. You can visit the cultural center and learn a little about Japanese culture while you at it. The place is clean and safe. Bear in mind it has seasonal hours and usually closes at dusk, while the park entry closes an hour earlier. I think in summer it closes around 6 pm, plan your visit accordingly.

Japan in Argentina. Has a quick visit today, around US $5. Very well kept and some great photo opportunities. The Koi carp are huge and you can buy pellets to feed them from the shop at the back of the gardens. Only takes 10 mins to walk around but if you take your time and enjoy a bit of peace of quiet, then you will enjoy.

Peaceful and beautiful gardens in the middle of a busy city. Lovely and exquisitely maintained garden with lots of birds, koi fish, and beautiful photo ops. There's a restaurant inside the garden grounds as well. The visitors center houses a small library of books on and about Japanese culture in several languages, including Japanese of course. It hosts an exhibition room and for the month of April it housed examples of Japanese art including dolls, kimonos, origami, flower arrangement, and more. 70 peso entry fee. Main entrance is on Avenida Casares. If you're prone to mosquito bites like I am, you might want to use your anti-bug spray/balm/repellant of choice.

Small and expensive. I hesitated between a 2 and 3 rating. The garden is nicely done but is is very small and the entry fees are very high (around 170 pesos for two) for what you get to see. We were hoping for a greenhouse with some old bonsais, but aside from a few to sell, there was nothing. We may be biased since in Montreal we have a very large and very nice japanese garden with a rich collection of century old bonsais. Unless you are a fan or have a lot if time on your hand, this is not worth it in my opinion.
Nothing speciel... I was a little bit disappointed. A nice garden, but not very Japanese. Really not anything special after my opinion. I was glad that the entrance was cheap.
Japan in argentina. Safe. Peacefull. Well done. Japanese excellence. Great details. Nice in the afternoon for walking and meditating
Feeling of Japan. very nice and relaxing, garden is beautiful, very nicely arranged, with plenty of flowers and plants tea, wonderful.
Very well kept. Wonderful gardens in the middle of the city. So well looked after. Many attractions and demonstrations. It is worth a visit.

Unless you came from Japan, please take some time and visit this park. This is one of the most well kept gardens in town, and it's really gorgeous. Beautifully designed with a good variety of trees and plants, nice paths and several tematic monuments. You can go to the bonsai garden (well, you are in Buenos Aires, not in Co Chi Ming) and have a nice breakfast, tea, lunch or dinner at the restaurant within the park.And you can feed the colourful fish in the lake if that suits you.

Oasis in a noisy city!. Not the gardens of Kyoto but a beautiful serene place to spend couple of hours. Nice and inexpensive flower shop.
Do not eat there! The restaurant is awful.

A place full of peace and beauty. A peacefull place to enjoy a calm afternoon. Many plans to admire and fishes to feed will make your visit funny, specially for kids. The restaurant is a bit expensive but there is a kiosk inside to buy something to drink and a snack.
Nice.. The entrance ticket is cheap, but the restaurant inside is very expensive. If you are looking for a different sight seeing in Buenos Aires, it's certanly a nice place to go.
Great afternoon stop. This is a great stop for a couple of hours or lunch when touring Recoleta area. Very relaxing place to chill for awhile.

Nice touch. The Japanese heritage in South America is hard for many norte-americanos to imagine. This garden -- maintained and staffed in large part by volunteers is rich with design and layouts of traditional Japanese design. Very restful.
Expensive, noisy.. When I picture a Japanese garden the first word that pops into my head I'd tranquillity. This place is anything but, it's beside a really busy/noisy road. It's small and expensive.
Not worth the money. Entrance to the gardens is pretty expensive and the gardens themselves are not very impressive. I would skip this unless you have nothing else to do.

Just Lovely. I was lovely to stroll around the perfect and interesting Japanese Garden. The fish ponds and bridges, art and trees, we're all just lovely. It was a beautiful sunny day and a great place to go with friends.

Beautifully done, kids enjoyed it. . Spent part of the afternoon here. $70 pesos for adults to get in. Children under six are free. Our kids really enjoyed walking around and taking it all in. $10 pesos will buy you a bag of fish food and you can feed the carp. They are huge and so many! Clean and decent bathrooms. Also, situated in a very walkable area. There is a playground across the street for young kids that we went to afterwards.
Overpriced!. It was nice, but Parque Holanda is just up the street, free, and nicer! I would skip this and go see the hundreds of roses at Parque Holanda.

Disappointed. Whenever I am travelling I always looks for chinese and japanese gardens. I love the beauty and tranquility. When I visited the garden in Buenos Aires there was a musical presentation and it was awesome so I`m keeping that in mind when I say that even without the music these gardens seemed to be missing the tranquility. The gardens were quite open and close to lots of roads - I didn`t spot any nooks or crannies where I could sit and people watch or read my book.
Peaceful, well arranged garden. They play some soothing music around the park, beautiful. There is a small museum inside the building at the end of the park. 70 peso for entrance to the park.
Fantastic place. I visited in 2013 with my mom.It was a sunny day.This garden is fabulous! There are many flowers to see.. It's very good to stay in contact with the nature.
Nothing special. The museum is nice as the park, but nothing special. I went there in march, maybe the season was not good.

Well looked after gardens great for a wander. This cost 70$, approx £5 when this was written and was well maintained. Very colourful and laid out well. We called here en route to florales from bosgues de palermo on a walk, which definitely added to a nice day

There are better Japanese Gardens. It is in a noisy environment and rather small. Through loudspeakers comes music. It is not so beautifull and tranquil as is possible. Above the overpriced bad value restaurant there is a nice exposition of japanese art. Entrance fee 70 pesos a person.
A great way to spend a spare hour. A beautiful Japanese garden but of a size that even in 35ºC is small enough a pleasant way to spend a an hour gently strolling or relaxing in the shade.
Beautiful gardens. Lovely gardens on the periphery of one of BAs main parks. Quite small and self contained with a cheap entry fee. A pleasant way to spend a couple of hours.

Tranquility even on a busy Sunday afternoon.. What a lovely space packed into a comparatively small area of parkland. As soon as you entered the garden, you can see vis of the flowers, trees and landscaping of the beautiful garden. Go inside the "welcome" building and go up the stairs to the "mirador" overlooking the garden for stunning views over the waterlily ponds. Loved walking over the boardwalks seeing the enormous koi carp. A very calm place in the middle of the city. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful. Visited in the Spring, classic Japanese Garden with pathways and ponds. The Coffee shop/restaurant is a little pricey but worth it. Great place to spend a couple of hours on a nice day.

A oasis of quietness in the centre of Buenos Aires traffic. The gardens made a lovely break in an otherwise busy, noisy tour of BA. They may be fairly small, but this means they don't take too much out of day to see. They are pretty and very well maintained.
Fit them in if you have time

Lovely Gardens. Our hotel was nearby so we popped in to look around.There is a small entrance fee with very good amenities inside.It's not a massive garden but beautiful al the same, it only takes an hour or at the very most two hours to amble around. I wouldn't make a special trip but if you have a spare hour or are nearby it's well worth a visit.

A pleasant interlude .... Mr Loafer and I spent a short afternoon here. It was well attended by visitors, although not too busy, during our walk. For a bit of relief from the City and providing a relaxation spot it was appreciated.

From pictures I was expecting more. This is a slightly underwhelming Japanese Garden in Palermo. I have visited many Japanese Gardens around the world and I have to say this was one of the more disappointing ones. It was still a pleasant place to walk around but if you're short on time in Buenos Aires I would definitely skip it.

Delightful escape from a not-very-exciting city. By day three of our visit to BA, having done the steaks, the tango show and La Boca, we were starting to wonder what else to do. We spent a delightful hour or so in the pristine Japanese Gardens and it remains one of the nicest memories of our stay - nothing sensational, just quiet, calm and very pretty.

Nice garden. I had heard and read about the garden. We were walking to Palermo, when I saw the sign and of course I wanted to see it. The garden claims they are the biggest. Japanese Garden outside Japan. Well, I don't know about that! I might be wrong but I think our Japanese Garden in Houston is about the same size if not bigger. They do have an entrance fee. You will find a Japanese restaurant inside which I later heard is a decent one (we did not go there). We only spent about 30 minutes inside the Garden. Overall it's nice if you want to sit down on a bench and relax a little bit.

Pleasant but Nothing Special. There are many beautiful Japanese gardens to tour outside of Japan. I recommend the one in Seattle or San Francisco. This one is modest and tranquil but certainly not worth making a destination item on your itinerary. You can feel comfortable not visiting it--secure in the knowledge that you missives nothing special.
A delight. This work of horticultural art is a definite must in This city. . It is beautifully landscaped and cared for . A memorable visit

Very pleasant but busy. These gardens were a good find after the disappointment of the Botanical gardens. Thoughtful layout, plenty of colour and well maintained, these small gardens are great for a gentle stroll or a welcome sit down. They were pretty busy when we visited and so not quite as restful as they surely are at quieter times. There's not a great deal to see but they are worth a visit all the same.

Tranquility. If you want some peace and quit fron the buzzling town, this is the plce to go. Maybe not the best japanese garden in the world, but has a nice park, you can buy fishfood for the huge koifish (kids love it!) and it has a really good sushirestaurant inside, and traditional teahouse.
Ok gardens, but seen better. Average, not bad, but not great either. We had recently arrived when we went, so possibly just expecting a bit more.

Poor example of a Japanese garden. I was visiting with my Chinese friend and since it was such a nice day and we were in the area we decided to walk through the garden. None of the plants or trees were labeled, the garden does not look well kept. We have both visited many Japanese gardens and this is not worth the time. There are a couple of red Japanese looking bridges and coi fish in the dirty water but a poor example of what a real Japanese garden would look like. Save your money and time, there are to many other things to do and see.

Surprisingly large gardens beautifully landscaped. These were a gift to the city by the Japanese government so very authentic in layout with gorgeous lakes, bridges, trees and of course plants. Plenty of shade if you go on a hot day and even a Japanese cafe selling japanese snacks!

Beautiful way to spend an afternoon!. My daughters and their two friends and I spent a beautiful afternoon in the garden. Very peaceful and relaxing. The music was lovely. We enjoyed tea and sandwiches in the restaurant.

GOOD FOR FAMILIES WITH SMALL KIDS.. I write this review as a mother of a 2 year old not as a normal human being. If you have small kids and you are about to loose it, take those rascals there, buy them some bags to feed the fish and enjoy peace for as long as those bags can last. Do not attempt this if your child is the sort that will try to jump in the water, the place is basically an artificial lake. It is pretty enough for a nice stroll for the parent to enjoy, or even normal childless human beings. It even has clean toilets and an outdoor food area.

Nice relaxing place, after a day of walking. My wife and I were walking the Recoleta area, found these gardens, and spent an hour relaxing, and viewing nicely presented gardens. Not the best Japanese gardens we have been to, but some of the largest carp we have seen.

A little Japan in Buenos Aires!. This is a magical and relaxing place! I love the nature and the beauty of this garden. There is a japanese restaurant and a nursery inside. It's perfect to share a special moment with your love or with friends! You can take beautiful pictures there as well! Enjoy it!

Too small!. Really nice but not big enough considering the entry fee of70pesos..Not much to see,very commercial but nice to see if you want to make the time to get there.You cover the whole area in minutes litarelly! Even if you take your time.Up to you to decide.
Recommended. Susana your suggestion was great. I felt almost like in Tokyo here. La comida en el restaurante es kmuy buena pero no es barata.

Nice for a walk in a beautiful setting. End of summer Sunday. Lots of families and great for photos. We had a late afternoon sandwich in the tea house which serves desserts but not sushi at that hour. It was a perfect thing to do on a gorgeous day

Beautiful and peaceful. Larger than it looks from the outside the Japanese Garden is an incredibly relaxing experienceIt closes rather early so go earlier in the day, there is a fee to go in but it's not prohibitive. The gardens are beautifully manicured and a perfect place to go for a date. Our favourite part was walking down the long wooden raised walkway (over the water) great place for photographs.
It just a big garden with flowers. Saw from the tour bus and went back wishing to see lots of flowers it had some, but not in abundance.

A lovely Japanese garden in the heart of Buenos Aires. It is worth visiting, and spending a moment of calm in the heart of vibrant Buenos Aires. That being said, by all means PASS on the restaurant of the same name. The food is very mediocre, service poor and prices very high. There is no lack of good food in Buenos Aires, and you don't go there for Japanese food, and the Japanese Garden restaurant will certainly not satisfy your desire for good sushi, sashimi or other Japanes food. Avoid.
Beautiful Gardens. This was the perfect relaxing way to spend my birthday afternoon. There is a great little restaurant where you can get sushi and you have a beautiful view of the garden.

Pretty little Japanese Garden. Pretty garden but nothing really special. Better things to see in Buenos Aires. I think there are more activities going on later in the day but we were there early in the morning so not much happening. Huge fish in the ponds but not enough signage for visitors in English.
A Beautiful Oasis. A beautiful, well-thought-out genuine Japanese garden. Very Zen. Has clean rest rooms, a little museum, a restaurant, and a snack bar.
Nice and relaxing garden. Really worth a visit, especially if you would like to relax a little. Even in hot summer the garden is very well maintained.
Beautiful!. The perfect place for a peaceful and calming stroll, quiet with no traffic noise. A lovely place to get away from the hub but of the city.
A nice change. I visited this garden 6 or 7 years ago and at the time it was a little shabby.Seeing it last week was a unexpected delight. Well maintained, clean with lot of visitors

Stunning peaceful garden. My hubby and I thoroughly enjoyed the day we spent at the Japanese Gardens. It is a beautiful and serene place which we need after the business of Argentina. You will enjoy it and would recommend you visit

A Romantic Stroll. We were in BA for our honeymoon and could not resist a chance to take a walk in a beautiful garden. The grounds are well maintained and despite being located in a buzzing metropolis, it was surprisingly tranquil. One of our favourite features was the display of Bonsai trees available at the nursery. We enjoyed reading about how they are grown and looking at the different varieties. A stroll in the garden hand in hand is a lovely way to spend an afternoon. If time permits, it’s also worthwhile to visit the onsite museum and appreciate Japanese works of art, instruments and traditional garments on display.
beautiful & tranquil. This is a lovely place to wander, sit and relax, a total oasis in the middle of BA. Close to Museo Malba and worth the visit.

Beautiful oasis . A wonderful place to spend the afternoon. My husband and I had lunch at the Japanese restaurant. That was a bit of a challenge since the waitress spoke little English, but we managed to enjoy everything we order. The food was a little pricey, but we expected that since it is in a tourist attraction. The gardens were well maintained and very serene. It's a wonderful escape from the busy traffic that surrounds it! Well worth the trip.
Recommended. Great place to eat delicious Japanese food. Everything was great here. Had an amazing time. Thank you for everything.

an oasis. great place of calm in a busy city. just walk around and relax . a fantastic place for families to relax. get there b4 the crowds. the restaurant is ok but pricey and the cashier is way too pushy in looking for extra tios. Wouldn't go back to the restaurant.

Relaxing in the garden on a hot day.. We went on a walk through the many parks and ended up in the Japanese Gardens. They are small but very relaxing and have a good Japanese Resturant and also a snack cafe in the grounds.

A little bit of cool and calm in a hot city. Although there were lots of people about and it was very hot, this garden felt cool and calm and we enjoyed the gentle noises from the Japanese water features.
Not special. Expected more Japanese plants it was a park with Japanese atmosphere. Not so many bonsai and perfect gardens with pebbles and stones

A beautiful and peaceful retreat. The Japanese Garden, though not large, is a beautiful oasis in Buenos Aires. The garden is well planned out and very well maintained. A relaxing way to spend time away from the more familiar tourist sites.

Small Garden in the City. From some previous reviews I had read the Japanese Garden was high on my list of places to see in Buenos Aires. I was a bit suprised at how small the garden was when I entered. Overall the gardens were well maintained although there were a few sections closed off for construction/upgrades. The Koi in the ponds were fun to watch and there were some interesting plants and statues. The gardens were nice but for someone who loves gardens and green space they left me a bit underwhelmed.
Pleasant but not amazing. We had a nice walk around the gardens but it is fairly small and I didn't think it was particularly special. Lots of kids running and shouting kind of ruined the ambience.

Hidden. Jewel!!. This hidden jewel is a wonderful place to visit
It has the most beautiful and huge koi fish
It has a restaurant a lots of fun
Outside is horse cartridges
And is breath taking
I recommend this place 100%
I visited few years ago

Worth going just to see the Koi Carp. Its a garden, its quite pretty and it does have a Japanese feel to it. If I had a few days in BA I don't think I would make a special visit....if you have a week then maybe on a sunny day it could be a good place to just relax and take a stroll. The most impressive thing about this garden in my opinion was the sheer numbers of koi carp in the lake and some of them are huge. I did go and have sushi at the restaurant (separate review) and I would advise against it as it is very expensive. There is a separate little place that sells ice creams and that would have been adequate refreshment. Overall it is nice but nothing special, some good photo opportunities so if you are in the area and want to chill out from the hustle and bustle of BA for an hour then give it a go.

Peace in the middle of the city. The garden was beautiful. Lovely walkways between waterways, small waterfalls and manicured grass and trees. Interestingly there is a memorial to the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima within the garden.There is a small pagoda with a large bell hanging within. No idea when it might be struck or how often.The water is full of fish, and is great fun for children to feed. When we were there there were two sizes of fish in the water, very large and just hatched.

A nice afternoon destination. I always find these types of gardens small and nothing surprising. But I still enjoy a walk around them ( maybe hoping to find a surprise!) If you are out walking among the many parks in the area, it is an enjoyable stop
Great for a walk thru. Pleasantly interesting and could stay for lunch but the crowd made it less charming. Lots of families because it was Sunday.
Experiencing Buenos Aires. These are one of the most intricate Japanese gardens that one can experience when travelling in South America.

Lovely Place to Walk. It is a beautiful, serene place to walk around. There were other visitors, but it wasn't crowded (although we visited in January, which I don't think is the height of the tourist season) and provided something different from the hustle-and-bustle of the city. Worth the visit!

Very nice garden in the "lakes area" of Buenos Aires. This garden is a nice (but a bit costy, ticket = 70 AR$) option for those searching for a bit of relax in the city of Buenos Aires. Located 10' walk from the Museum of Latinamerican Art, it is really an oasis of peace, even though the proximity to the airport Aeroparque Newberry does not really allow a full relax (at least from noise).
A piece of Japan. This Japanes Garden is very well kept, you can enjoy nature Japanese style. The Japanese Restaurant in the Garden is also worth a visit.
A bit small. I expected it bigger but it's still a nice oasis in the middle of Buenos Aires' hustle and bustle. Good place to visit especially on a hot afternoon!
A Nice Respite. Relaxing and beautiful setting. 70 pesos for admission seems reasonable. An oasis in a very busy city especially on a hot day.

Go out and take some photos. Everyone enjoys the atmosphere of this Japanese garden.
Near museums and fancy neighbourhoods you stop and relax.
Teenagers taking pictures. Ladies having tea. Families buying bonsai trees.
Colours everywhere you go.
It can be a little crowded on holidays.

Nice area, not much space to sit . If you like gardens, then do not miss these ones. However, be aware that if you visit in the summer time, it gets very very hot and there is not much shadow and spaces to sit.

no big deal. if you have traveled at all, or your hometown has a botanical garden, and your pressed for time, don't do this. it's a once around the small park with some nice trees, poorly mainatined, with hundreds of koi. go have a long lunch instead.

Overpriced. Inexpensive - but there are lots of nice parks in Buenos Airies with no entrance charge. The park was absolutely packed with people. It was pretty with gardens and ponds filled with large koi. However, if you're expecting something really special, like intricate bonsai gardens, you'll be disappointed.

Pretty authentic!. I lived in Japan for several years and really grew to appreciate what a Japanese garden is all about. When I saw this garden in BA, I was blown away with the sheer scale of it! Big and open, but somehow still "tight" and authentic.

A moment of peace. Nobody expect a perfect silence in the middle of the city rounded by 2 of the main avenues. The koi fishes, the green, the sakura in spring is incredibly beautiful, quiet and perfect! The maintenance is always perdect and clean. The food, the shops and everything inside is a little Japan!

Not that unique. The Japanese garden is special, as it's in the middle of a very european and south-american city, but that's about the only thing. Not really a place I would recommand to anyone again.

Nice place to walk around, touristy. The Japanese Garden is nice to walk around but there are a lot of tourists and you have to pay to get in. Maybe better for families with kids who want the experience. For my husband and I coming from the states, we didn't think it was really worth it. But we took some nice pictures and it was an ok way to spend an hour.

Very pretty but not spectacular . Nice to visit if in the area but not worth the money to go see (although cheap). Highlights were the koi fish and bonsai trees! The grass wasn't lush however it was well kept.
Gorgeous gardens. If you can't get to Kyoto, this is the next best thing! Magnificent gardens, ponds, stones, and a nice cultural center as well. Wonderful way to spend an afternoon.

Elegant, relaxing, well maintained and free for senior visitors.. When in Palermo, do not miss the opportunity to visit this elegant garden. It has been built by the Japanese community of Buenos Aires to provide - on top of a pleasant place where to spend some hours of relax - a number of cultural activities and exchange trips with their motherland. Lakes, bridges, perfectly maintained lawns, plenty of different trees and birds characterise the Japanese Garden. The restaurant is currently closed, but a bar provides refreshments and snaks. A Bonsai garden sells various types of plants and provides a sort of "hospital" for suffering bonsais. Very pleasant is the fact that the senior citizens (all national and foreigners over 65) enter for free, saving 70 Pesos of ticket.
Interesting but nothing special. Good for a short walk. Very touristy at small space. Expected bigger territory. To small for a long walk.
Pit Stop. Ok to visit if you happen to be in the area but don't plan your day around it. Not that exciting to make too much of an effort.
Rosie Miilar. It was our last day in BA and a hot holiday weekend. The gardens were very busy. I expected moss and stone gardens which werent but the site was pleasant.
Pleasant stroll. We had passed this in a taxi and I was keen to go. It was quite compact but pleasant to wander through. There was a restaurant and little shop.

A bit disappointing. This Japanese garden was not up the brilliance of some that we have seen around the world and we would definitely recommend seeing Recoleta Cemetery as the number one choice if you are pushed for time in your visit to Buenos Aires

Would have been nice if free. While the admission price is not exorbitant, I did not feel we got our money's worth in this fairly small enclosed garden (roughly 1 city block in size). This garden sits on the edge of a park in the Palermo section of BsAs and has a nice pond, large koi, a little bridge over the pond, some beautiful plantings and some small sculptures. It is peaceful and it is pretty and can be a nice place to come and sit, but while I don't remember the exact price of admission, I remember thinking at the time it seemed excessive for what one got. However, if you have a little extra time and a little extra money while in BsAs, its not a bad place to go
Poorly maintained gardens with entry fee?!. Love Japanese gardens, this one was very overgrown and tired with sections closed off and broken bridges and fountains. Disappointing and uninspiring..
A surprise oasis: free for seniors but $150 pesos otherwise. Pretty and small garden tucked in the hustle-bustle of Buenos Aires. Very large koi. Maybe could spend about 1.5 hours here at the most.
Calm and peaceful . A calm and peaceful place to visit. A charming garden with some interesting information about the Japanese relationship with Argentina.

Very pretty but a bit disappointing . Amongst the hustle and bustle of BA this is a nice spot to get away from it all - although it is a popular spot and there are lots of tourists with selfie sticks being swung around so in actual fact one of the parks is probably a better spot to retreat from the city!The garden itself is very pretty and well looked after but having paid the slightly expensive entrance fee I was quite disappointed by the size of the garden. It's very small and will take you about 10 minutes to walk around - and that's at a slow pace! There isn't much to read and the only exhibition panel is all in Spanish which was also a little disappointing. We also tried the restaurant. Maybe the standard of Sushi in London is better but it was pretty bad in this restaurant. I'd try elsewhere for sushi. I suppose it's worth a look if either you have nothing to do or are passing by but I'm not sure I would go out of my way to go to it.
Lovely garden. Beautifully landscape garden which was a gift from Japan. Lovely place to walk with ponds and Koi and beautiful plants.

Not worth the entrance fee or a walk to visit.. $70 peso entrance fee. We were really disappointed. The parks we walked through to reach the Japanese gardens were far more impressive. It took us 15 mins to walk around including a loo stop. It felt very 'Dsneyesque' but without the magic of Disney.

Very pretty and serene. It's like being in one of the parks in Tokyo, where you can find yourself in a little oasis amidst all the urban stuff. We felt the tearoom here was very overpriced (though pretty), so we didn't eat here, and the other spot marked on the map as having food really only had chips and ice cream. While this was not on our list of must-sees, it was a nice stop on a sunny day.

Small but perfectly formed. A real oasis of peace and calm as you might expect from a Japanese garden. It's not huge but it is well put together and a very peaceful location to while away an hour or so. they had an exhibition of kimonos on when we were there. Not many but a nice diversion and in out of the hot sun. You can feed the koi carp if you want. The big fish are huge (it would take a lot of chips to go with them!). I've been in Japan and seen some amazing gardens there and whilst this isn't on the same scale or have the same grandeur it is still worth the visit and the AR$50 to get in.

Gardens & lunch . A pleasant place for a walk & light sushi lunch- feeding the large koi carp was the highlight for us There are some lovely roses & Japanese trees & lots of lovely lily pads growing in the ponds which are brimming with massive koi carp fish

disappointing as a garden. not really much of a Japanese garden. lacking in much of the traditional Japanese landscape architecture and no bonsai to speak of. On the positive side we didn't pay to get in as they accepted a photocopy of our passports as proof that we are seniors.

Pretty but not imprasove. There were some pretty flowers and areas to sit to people watch but not sure it was worth the entrance fee. Only took us ten minutes to walk through and that's even with stopping to take photos.

A Peaceful Stop in Parque 3 de Febrero. This is a place to appreciate the Japanese ambiance. It is peaceful and well taken care of. Ponds are full of huge fish, eager to be fed. Water in the ponds when we were there was very murky. There is a tea house where apparently a limited number of visitors can sign up to experience the ceremony held there. The garden includes three trees transplanted from Hiroshima or Nagasaki that survived the blast. There is a small cultural center that we did not spend too much time exploring. A restaurant is part of the center.

Nice garden but to small. Very pretty garden with lots of flowers, trees and birds. It is a nice walk but the garden is very small and the food inside is rather expensive. A bit to much of an 'amusementpark' to my taste.

Unexpected and wonderful. I came upon this by accident on my first trip to Argentina two years ago and visited again this past week. It was built in the 1960s and has been beautifully maintained. I doubt you'd see anything like this anywhere else outside of Japan. The sushi restaurant inside the park is also a really nice respite from the ubiquitous steak meal. It's also relatively close to Recoleta Cemetary, which makes it easy to do both in a couple of hours.
Sight see. This is part of the great park areas that are so prevalent in Buenos Aires very well done and lovely tranquil good for an easy hour or two
A quiet place in a humorous city. There's this eery feeling you get while going around the garden. Is a quiet place in such a frantic city.

Not Turning Japanese. It didn't help that it was a scorching hot day and I had just walked for miles through bustling streets and avenues to get here, but it wasn't the oasis of oriental calm I had expected. It was much larger than I'd imagined, but the size didn't add to making it impressive. It was just more of the same thing: little fish-filled ponds, cute little bridges, pagodas, bushes on and on. Outside, roaring traffic hurtles past unceasingly. It's a park but its parkiness is undercut by being intersected by highways full of traffic. This garden is an approximation of what someone brought up on Disney films, but hadn't actually seen an actual garden, might think a Japanese garden should look like.

Great way to chill after a long flight. My partner and I went to he gardens the day after we arrived in the city. The garden is beautiful and just the right size to enjoy. The coy are as big as cats and they follow you like dogs as you walk the bridges.

Loved it!. Japanese gardens are, of course, usually beautiful and well maintained. So no surprise here. But here it still feels like such a special place, like this little oasis in this huge city. A true haven of tranquility. Absolutely loved it.Costs 50 pesos to get in. Totally worth it!!

Tranquil Spot. On my last day in BA, I took a cab to the Japanese Garden and spent a little over an hour just taking in the beauty of the gardens, and watching the fishes. I also stopped by the restaurant for a drink on my way out. I thought it was a lovely way to spend my last morning in BA away from the crowds.

Very nice but not quite a true Japanese garden. It is pretty and well worth a stroll but having been to Japan it doesn't quite ring true. However don't be put off by this. It is a pleasant picturesque place to spend some gentle time in this vibrant city.There really is no need to book a tour as it is easy to find and not very large. It is a bit of a walk from public transport though A visit of 2 hours would probably suit most people. If you come in summer a hat or umbrella would be handy as the garden isn't completely in shade. Also bring water to drink and if you want a little food for the fish(carp) some of which are huge.

Small, but Lovely. After a long day of sight seeing we were on our way back to the hotel when we saw this garden and decided to walk through to go to the other side of the area. It was very pretty, but the noise from the street could still be heard. We are seniors, and if you can prove you are one, you can get in for no charge.

The perfect combination of flowers and fishes. At the Japanese Garden you can enjoy a nice atmosphere, not only because of the great variety of flowers and colourful fishes it has, but also the relaxing music you can listen to while walking through the nice paths that leads the visitor to different stands where history, bonsais and souvenirs make visiting this place worthwhile . Enjoy it with all your senses!

I don't understand the other reviews. A very quick summary .. The best thing about this is the koi carp in the ponds. If you've seen some of the Japanese gardens in Kew Gardens this doesn't even come close. On top of this the staff in the shop inside were grumpy!

Beautiful Quiet Place for a Stroll. Access to the garden is easy and the grounds are well maintained. There are many shaded areas to sit and meditate. The Coy Pond is massive and well stocked. The gift shop has a good variety of authentic items made in Japan. Note: Seniors over 65 receive free access.

Pleasant place to spend a little time. This had most of the elements of a traditional Japanese garden, but I was a little disappointed by its small size, having walked for over an hour to get there, and had to pay to go in - entry is theoretically free for retired people, but you have to show your passport, which we had left in the hotel safe as instructed by our tour rep.

Lovely....but super busy. We visited on a bank holiday, as it was one of the few places open - we hadn't thought to check whether there were any Saints days falling on our trip but found there were two. This basically meant that everyone who fancied a day out....seemed to be in the Japanese Gardens!!! It is beautiful, and worth a visit, but as part of the point is the tranquility and peace, I really would advise trying to visit at a time when you think it might be quiet - morning on a normal week day for example.
Calm in the busy city. The Japanese Gardens are beautiful, peaceful and quirky. Have a good time strolling along the paths and over the bridges watching the Koi. Good place to chill out.
Lovely place even when busy. Lovely place even when busy but restaurant was pricey and slow though the food was very good. Nice art exhibition when we were there

OK but not great example. It has many elements of a Japanese garden but doesn't quite seem to capture the essence of a peaceful, serene environment.There are bonsai, koi, couple of bridges, a pagoda and a little waterfall. The free parks in the area far surpass this one.

Japanese trip in Buenos Aires. Sunny day in Buenos Aires, leaving the subway in the Plaza Italia station. You have to walk through the Zoo. This area nearby the Japanese garden is great in the sunny day. A lot of people, beautiful people. The Japanese Garden is great, it's a rewarding time to be here. Don´t miss that, it's unbelievable organized and clean.
Best garden. I went to this November it's great a grade so you will enjoyed it there if you are in bunes aires you must visit in there
Ok gardens. These gardens are small and just fair. Have been to lots nicer and quaint Japanese Gardens, which I personally love, but this one was ok.

nice place. we went to garden from an advice of a friend. its a nice place, pretty gardens and very well kept. but its a smal place in the end and you can see the whole of it in 30 minutes, so i dont know if the money worth it...

Peacefull Garden. Well worth a visit, it is kept impeccably and the garden with its bonzi trees justifies a visit. Furthermore it is about 500 yards from the Rose Garden situated in 3rd February Park.

Nice. The garden was certainly very nice, although a bit small and left something to be desired. The main draw seems to be the large center pond with plenty of koi, but there seem to be a lack of flowers that one would expect in a Japanese garden. There was a nice rose bud section, but it was very small. Overall, not necessary for a visit.
Just gorgeous!. A very chic and beautiful space. Spent a couple of hours there - I love gardens and this one is really special. The Koi ponds are really something
Beautiful small place, a little overpriced. Is beautiful, just perfect for take some pictures, nothing else. A little expensive comparing what this place offers (50 pesos or 5 USD aprox,)

Nice but Crowded..... A nice place to visit in the surroundings of Recoleta and the Palermo Parks, its a japanese cultural centre that represents honorably their society. Well design and set up, it display several of the typical features of a japanese garden with a couple of tori's in the back, a fish pond with a walkable path and even has a dojo for events.It also features a very popular restaurant next to the garden store, that offers a very traditional menu (you have to pay the entrance fee of the garden if you want to go to the restaurant). The garden itself its a very nice place to relax during the mornings but its quite crowded during the afternoons and the weekends so plan ahead and be smart.

Reminded me of Tokyo. Having planned to visit the Japanese Garden on my eighth day in Buenos Aires, this had to be postponed as the weather was abysmal all morning with heavy rain covering the city. So after having a long lunch a couple of miles away and waiting for the rain to disappear, it did and I took advantage of the time left to pay a visit to the Japanese Garden which is usually open from 10.00-18.00 arriving for the last hour. It was probably quieter than it would have been on a better weather day. The sky was now blue and the sun was back out and seeing the garden was an absolute treat. It really is beautiful and reminded me of my visit to the Japanese capital earlier in the year. The entrance fee is currently AR$50 which is pretty good value. There are also places to eat and shop there too. Well worth a couple of hours while in Buenos Aires

not sure. this place is located in a really nice district (Recoleta) but you have to pay for the entry and it gets crowdy really quick. So I am not sure if it is worth to see it. Technically, there is a tea ceremony but I did not see it because we decided it is not worth it because of the huge crowd.

Nice to have in the city. I am terribly spoiled by having experienced the gardens of Tokyo and Kyoto, and several wonderful examples like the tea gardens in San Francisco, so the comparison in my mind was unfavorable. However, having this nice park to visit with examples of Japanese horticulture is a very good thing for Buenos Aires, and I applaude the initiative. The park seemed a little neglected, but again, I'm coming from a very high expectation of what Japanese gardens should reflect......perfection!

Japan in Buenos Aires. The Japanese Gardens are wonderful. The small bridges, the iris growing in water along the walks , where there are benches so you can sit and just soak in the peace and quiet and beauty of the Gardens. There is a Tea House, a Gift Shop where you can buy plants, tea cups and a wonderful variety of things. There is a greenhouse where you can buy plants .. it is definitely worth stopping and visiting .. even more than once.

Lovely garden; Japanese restaurant even better. Our rented studio in Palermo Hollywood was within walking distance of the park where we discovered the Japanese Garden. Being from Portland, OR where it boasts one of the best in the country, I was pleasantly surprised to find this lovely garden, ideal for a leisurely stroll with a stop at the Japanese restaurant in the park. The food was excellent and I enjoyed the sashimi and deep-fried ice cream that was highly recommended by the Argentine couple sitting at the next table. It was fun to practice our Spanish and for the couple to practice their English. A lovely day in the park and meeting this lovely couple added to our memorable experience in Buenos Aires.

Nice place to go on a sunny day, the restaurant is good but expensive for the quality of the food they serve. Gardens are well maintained and very nice organized. On weekends gets very crowded therefore is advisable to go during the week

Distinctly average. If you've been to the amazing Japanese garden in San Francisco, this is a very very poor relation. That said, it's quite a pleasant place to spend an hour or so if you just want to have a quiet time. I certainly wouldn't make a special trip to see it.

Probably one of the most beautiful and peaceful places in BA. Hidden in between two of the busiest avenues in Buenos Aires is the Japanese Garden. Forget the location, it's peaceful and quiet and full of soul. Perfect spot to sit down and enjoy the sun on a spring or summer day while reading your book. You can always have a small break and enjoy a Japanese tea at the tea rooms, or go a little bit later and enjoy an amazing Japanese meal at the restaurant. The kids will love feeding the fish.
Peaceful Place!. Great stop for a quick visit. Got some yummy japanese ice cream as a snack. Good for pictures and just relaxing. The sushi restaurant is supposed to be the best in Buenos Aires.

transported to Japan. The gardens are lovely, with lots of fish to feed and the greenhouse has beautiful plants including bonsai. Don'd miss having a meal at the very authentic Japanese restaurant on the premises.

A corner of peace and asian taste in the heart of Buenos Aires. The Japanese Garden is a good representation of a Japanese garden that could be found in Tokio. Although small in size, gives the visitor a good idea of the style and views of Japanese Gardens. There are nice exhibitions from time to time.
Was hoping for more . We walked out to see the gardens. Nice enough but small and very open to the streets and flats around it. Ok if you are near or very keen but not sure I would bother again.

Small. The restaurant is the nicest feature. The Japenese garden is nice but very small. There is however a very good Japanese restaurant that makes it worthwhile to visit. Do take into account that there is a 50 pesos per person entrance fee that you will have to pay even if you only want to visit the restaurant.
Beautiful garden best sushi. I can spend here whole day. Nice relaxing. Very beautiful. Amazing restaurant. Don't forget your camera. A piece of Japan in the middle of Argentina

Nice please but not very big. I like all the Japanese culture and this place is a tiny representation of it.Two things that I didn't like were that there is a lot of people walking around, a lot of kids also yelling and running around, so if you wanna be there sitting and relaxing for a little bit this is not the place to do it.The place is also tiny and the park benches are all the time occupied due to the amount of people that go there, so it was difficult to find a place to sit down.The only thing I like is that is a tiny piece of japan's culture.

Not really worth the detour. This is an admittedly nicely maintained Japanese-like garden, but very full on week-ends and with really not much to see unless you're fond of ugly large koi fishes or families with multiple kids. Entry expensive (for what it is). You'll be better of walking in the surrounding nice and free public parks.
