beautiful gardens. get lost in he japanese garden, watch the fish, buy yourself a bonsai trees or just enjoy in spring the beautiful diversity of flowers.

A tranquil sanctuary in a busy city. We visited the garden on the final day of a recent visit to Buenos Aires. After the fairly hectic pace of city life during the preceding three days, the garden provided the perfect opportunity to sit and relax in beautiful and calm surroundings and reflect on our fantastic stay in BA.The garden is so well laid out with typical Japanese attention to detail and it is horticulture at its very best. We spent almost 3 hours both exploring the garden and sitting in quiet contemplation. A perfect ending to a wonderful holiday.

Tranquil respite from busy BA. This wonderfully groomed garden has been one of the highlights of our trip to Buenos Aires. It's so serene and peaceful. In traditional Japanese style, the gardens are expertly staged for beautiful vistas at every turn. The ponds are full of colorful coi that happily meander right up to the banks in search of food. For the nostalgic and history buffs, there are a few tree species that that been preserved from Japan after the Hiroshima bombings. You can walk the gardens in an hour without trouble. It costs 50 pesos per person at the time of this writing. We got a bit hungry from the walk and randomly stepped into the Japanese Garden sushi restaurant. While pricey, the fish was outstanding: fresh, tender, and full of clean flavors (not at all fishy). I'm a sushi snob and can confidently state that the fish rivaled the quality we regularly get in NYC.

Jardin Japones. If near Palermo district in Buenos Aires you will have to go and see Jardin Japones - the Japanese Garden! The entrance fee is 50 pesos and even in a cloudy day like when I visited, the place was quite crowded. The perfect harmony between nature, fish, birds and humans will impress you for sure, and make your day and unforgettable one. Enjoy!

Noisy and scale/ proportions wrong. Cars roaring past on two of the busiest roads in BA and a pack of dogs barking outside the gardens for the whole of our visit meant the garden was not at all peaceful.I lived in Japan and this garden was not recognisable to me as a Japanese garden. The scale and proportions were wrong and only a cursory nod to the elements to include but no thought on how to bring them together.
Stunning. Stunning garden, very well designed and impecable maintainance. Entrance costs 50 pesos. In the surroundings there are plazas and public gardens, just wonderful.

A piece of Japan in Buenos Aires. I love this place. Walking the garden is very relaxing, the cafeteria serves some japanese sweets, and they have an auditorium which I had the chance to visit when attending a business event. The gift shop offers a variety of souvenirs for every budget, and they also have workshops for Japanese crafts

beaituful peaceful retreat in the heart of all the noise. peaceful, quiet, and very well maintained and organized location. there is a small entry fee but this is justified because clearly there is a lot of maintanance done on this garden. well worth a visit to rest your feet after exploring palermo

Lovely!. I took soooo many photos of this place! It´s really wonderful how was designed and they take care about this place. I went a sunny day and wow! I could have stayed for sooo long,chilling peacefully!

Very nice break. Before coming to Buenos Aires, we tried to chose between Tokio and BA, and we decided to go BA. After seeing this place in the middle of the city, we did not want to miss it and, to some extent, it we saw Tokio, too :D The entrance fee is 50 peso, which is quite fair, and you can spend 1.5-2 hours in this garden. For photographers, you can catch lots of beautiful scenes. Come prepared.

Lovely place. This is a lovely place well in reach of Jorge Newbery airport, and if you like walking as much as I do, you can even leave your bags in the airport and wander to that place, enjoying Buenos Aires, as I did.Its beautiful, and you can feed the fishes buying fish food right there - its funny to serve the pigeons too. Theres a nice restaurant serving sushi inside the park complex.
Loved this place. Loved this place really liked the restaurant special plates and helado frito is my favorite dessert I recommend it to all my friends thank you very much
Beatiful. 50 pesos charge. Was worth the money tho. Well kept garden, beautiful flowers, obese carps. They are fun to watch, as are birds fishing! Overall a fun stroll.

Japanese Beauty in the heart of BA!. Incredible garden in the heart of Buenos Aires. It costs about Ar$50 per person to get in, so plan for that as it is not free like the oher botanical gardens close by. The garden is well worth the visit is you are in BA.
Wonderful. Very well taken taken care of and beautiful at every sense. I spent a half day and there could not get enough. Alao try the restaurant it is amazing

Amazing juxtaposition against the urban mammoth. Beautiful and relaxing. Cheap entrance fee to experience a very unique experience. Unique in the sense of this being the largest true Japanese garden outside of Japan and visited by Japanese royalty every now and then.

Not for the people who saw Japan. It is quite simple. If you have not been to Japanese Gardens in Japan, you will like this place. Cozy, clean, refreshing and they have a nice restaurant, however if you have been in Japan and visited the gardens over there, you will see an average imitation of the real ones. So it really depends on the past experience. The cookies that are sold in the garden shop are delicious though.

Stunning Japanese Garden. There is an entrance fee but it is well worth it. The gardens are very tranquil and pleasant. We especially loved the date planted with grass. This garden is wonderful for photography and makes a change from the huge city blocks.There is also a nursery section for locals to buy plants.Highly recommended!
A piece of Japan in Buenos Aires. Adorable place to walk, relax, feel peace and meditate, or to enjoy some of the numerous activities promoted by the Association.
Peaceful Place. Went there with friends and family. Japanese Garden was very relaxing and peaceful. Attractions were very nice.

Looks pretty.. The Japanese garden in Palermo, Buenos Aires are a feast for the eyes. It is wonderfully aesthetic, creatively laid out, and I highly recommend going. It is open to 18.00 in the afternoon and cost 50 peso. Inside there is a Japanese restaurant, that looks good. Kind of expensive, and I have not tried it, so I can't vouch for the quality. The only thing I missed was areas to sit for longer periods. The benches were not really comfortable.
Nice but overpriced.. Nice place to relax after an afternoon walking around the city, but I don't think there is enough to see to justify the 50 pesos entry fee.
OK. The water is very green, but there are a lot of giant fish and birds. If you have a lot of time in the city, pay a visit. If not, there are a ton of other better things to see.

Beautiful Japanese Culture in the heart of Buenos Aires. I used to go here when I was a little kid to feed the Koi... I went back here just this past year after 25 years and it was just like I remembered it as a little kid. Great place to spend a few hours and walk around with family, by yourself or a significant other. Go to the back building and spend $1 to buy a bag of Fish Food, it's a great time and it holds a place in my heart forever.

Take a break. If you enjoy culture and nature you can’t miss this Japanese Garden. Experience a sunny morning in this rich and harmonious Japanese design. Sit on a bench by the lake, read a book, or simply breath in the fresh air.

Very nice japanese garden, well built and maintained!. Besides the Japanese Garden being a very well built and maintained garden, the surrounding areas also offer parks and activities (planetarium galileu galiei, zoo, etc) to spend a cool and calm day in Buenos Aires. Recommended for groups, couples or alone (make sure you set a nice playlist for the day).
Calm garden in the busy city. Spend some time enjoying the Koi, monuments, vegetation, art and the Japanese bell. Too bad we cannot all ring it. And don't forget to feed the fish.

A perfect little spot. It is not a big place, but it got so many nice things that you wanna take your time admiring them. Totally worth it. They usually also got different activities (such as expos, Gardening Workshop.. )

Nice and quiet. While its only walking distance from a major road, the zoo and the planetarium it is quiet and calm! My daughter loved walking around looking at all the giant Koi fish, traveling across the bridges and looking at the waterfall. My husband and I enjoyed looking at all the Bonzi trees and strolling through on a sunny day! It is stroller friendly for those with small children, the paths are wide and accessible. You can purchase food to feed the Koi which is a hit with most small children!A nice retreat from a busy day in the city!Warning: only restaurant near by is in the park so either pack a lunch, eat at the park or go for a walk around the city!
Take a book and chill. Overwhelmed with the hustle and bustle of BA. These gardens provide a great sanctuary. Peace and tranquility.

One lovely place. If you want to walk in a peaceful place. This is your place. you can spend hours without noticing. After you stay there for a while, you have some inner peace that you never notice before.

PEACE WITHIN THE CITY. This is an amazing place inside Buenos Aires. When you visit it, it feels like you are not in the city anymore. There is a variety of plants, trees, birds and fish. The Bonsai trees and the sculptures contribute to create an amazing environment. There is alsoo good food and people can find different courses including Japanese language and origami. There is a little store where you can buy souvenirs and snacks.

Peaceful and relaxing!. It's beautiful to go any time, but if you can go in the morning, DO IT!Very calm and peaceful to walk along the river and take pictures.The last time I go there I've payed $50 - per person.
Nice, even in the winter. This is a lovely place to stroll through. We enjoyed a Japanese tea after. Although we were there before dinner, the suishi preparations looked promising!
japanse gardens not well kept. this used to be a nice promenade, however it is now pretty abandoned, there is a pathetic cafeteria inside, very unispiring place
Peaceful place. My family really enjoyed visiting the Japanese garden, with its quaint bridges and islands. It is a place to escape from the noise and traffic.

don't bother. I am a garden fan and have been lucky enough to visit Japan several times and see many beautiful gardens there. I have also visited quite a few Japanese gardens in other countries including a couple close to Brisbane Australia where I live - this one would be near the bottom of my list! To me it had a "Disney' feel and no soul. What more can I say? I know others have liked it, perhaps they have not seen many Japanese gardens?

the island of tranquility in the middle of modern city. for the lovers of Japanese culture is the island of Japan spirit in the huge city of Buenos Aires, that is actually far from the Land of the rising sun.
not woth it. the garden is not maintain and let to nature. not much to see there and should be removed from the place to visit.
Far away. Far from town. Had to pay to get into the garden. It small and hard to spend more than an hour there. As it is a long away from town I would not go again.
Mini Japan. I've been in Japan and although its obviously not the same, you really feel like you are somewhere else than this country. A really silent, quiet and peacefull place.
Visit also the delta with the river islands. In spring time Escobar is the flower city of Argentina, you can visit the exposition, is 40 km from Buenos Aires, also the zoo in a natural place,
Beautiful and peaceful getaway. Totally worth relaxing one or two of hours in this oasis in the middle of a city that literally never sleeps, specially if you can avoid weekend crowds.

Beautiful gardens. We enjoyed the gardens along with the coit fish in the ponds. The gardens have different oriental plants and trees. It also has a nice oriental bridge that you can cross. It is a nice garden to visit and spend time to enjoy.
Beautiful!!!!. I love to go there! Just look at the pictures and you can see that it's gorgeous. It's not free but it's not expensive (around 5 dollars).
Different! A must!. This place is both beautiful and peaceful. I enjoyed it tremendously, the admission is $50 pesos which isn't bad at all.

Peace and armony in the middle of the city. The gardens are so beautiful. We got our names drawn by a Japanese girl. We watch a judo exhibitions. Some girls passed by with their kimonos for a tea ceremony. A learning experience for mi kids of a glorious ancient culture. We loved it!!!

Beautiful and Serene!. Just a delightful and beautiful piece of quite in the midst of a exciting city! A perfect place to come and relax and regroup before heading off to your next adventure! Very well kept and maintained with places to sit and enjoy the view.

Fine for two hours,but nothing extraordinary. The Japanese garden is certainly a pleasant enough place to visit,but I can't say that it's anything extraordinary.There are many other gardens in the world which are more beautiful.

Was it worth it?. I'm not sure. We spent some time sitting in the garden which was lovely but it's really small when we walked about. I don't see it as a great example of a Japanese garden and we might well of had just the same experience.

Nice garden, but rather crowded on the weekend. Nice garden and quite expansive, considering the location. Walking paths around ponds, over bridges to little islands. Admission fee seemed rather expensive, and the ambience was perhaps spoilt by the number of people present (we visited on a weekend). Welcome break from the hot, dry city.
Exquisite!. Do not miss this garden! Totally gorgeous! Lots of photo opportunities and beautiful water spaces! To add to the fun, there is a very fun gift shop!

Delightful. The last time we walked through the Gardens was at the end of 2008. Motivating us today was the beginning of an exhibit of Japanese kimonos that is only going to be on view until May 3rd.We thoroughly appreciated the japanese prints on the stairway leading to the Gallery of kimonos....and enjoyed them also. Making the visit more appreciated was the conversation we had we with Carola, a great employee and fun person.On our way out, Leonardo struck up a conversation with us. He is studying japanese 7 hours /day and his English was not bad either. We exchanged email addresses.As in 2008, we responded to the "feel" of Japan. We spent time in Japan in the early 1970's. The trees, the island, the carp in the water and the bridges all add to the ambience. AND the temps were perfect on this sunny day.
Spectacular views. The Japanese garden has spectacular views, the landscape is incredible. It is a nice tribute to the japanese - argentinian community.
a wonderful garden inside the Bosques de Palermo. One of the world's nicest Japanese gardens outside Japan, it offers a beautiful scenery with trees, ponds, fishes.You can eat inside as well.

Amazing. Really awesome garden, you are suddenly in Japan. The staff is Japanese, the shops sell Japanese stuff and you can also go to the restaurant inside the garden. The food is expensive and is not authentic.

Japan comes to South America. I love visiting Japanese Gardens and would say this was a nice one. Only thing spoiling it was the modern high rises nearby. Which I liked in themselves, but takes you away form the sereneness of this garden. There are several water areas and bridges. One bridge even leads to a little island which is especially popular with kids to climb up. Nice landscaping and beautiful year around. I like that when I'm here, people are actually generally quiet and respectful of the calm intent of these gardens.

Better when the Japanese embassy ran it1. A calm and beautiful Japanese garden, with a large pond full of multicoloured carp. There is a restaurant, not very Japanese, much more fusion, not cheat, and no¡t worth a visit. There are many people walking around, specially the days entrance is free. Since it is no longer run by the Japanese Embassy. It is more commercial, more places for coffee, tea and snacks. More and less delightful bonzai (dwarf trees) for sale. I still like to walk around at the less crowded times - early or late.
An Oasis of Tranquility in the City. Very nice and well maintained Japanese garden where you can spend a couple of hours relaxing and appreciating nature.

A Little Bit of Japan in Buenos Aires. A beautifully kept and well designed garden with koi ponds, japanese bridge and a restaurant where you can get sushi. We went during a special 3 day festival which included taiko drummers, music, martial arts displays, and an art show of delicate watercolors. Seniors can enter the gardens for free. They also have a nursery where you can buy plants and herbs at reasonable prices. A worthwhile visit on the way to the MALBA art museum.

Charming Japanese Gardens meets South America. This is a charming garden filled with Japanese Bonsai trees and Koi ponds. They have photo ready scenery and a lovely Japanese Restaurant on the property. I live on the west coast, so I am partial to our lovely gardens that flourishes in our climate, but if you don't have access to Japanese inspired gardens, the this is as close as you can get. They have snacks carts that are available too if you get hungry and thirsty.

A must in Buenos Aires. This small well-preserved garden is a good choice if you are looking for a quiet and nice place before lunch. You can hire a bicycle at the design shopping in Plaza Francia and ride across all the parks to there ( there is a cycle path all the way down). The restaurant inside is a good choice too, all sushi is so good and pretty affordable.

Well maintained Garden. This is the one of the good places to visit in BA. Unfortunately, the charges are very high as compare to the area of the garden and the kind of attractions they have inside. If you like to visit gardens, then you will love it for sure.

Peaceful Oasis. We went on a Tuesday, knowing that the entrance would be free.The lady at the ticket office charged us anyway. I mentioned that I thought it was free on Tuesdays so she asked for our ages, we are seniors so she let us in free.The Garden itself is very beautiful. It is not big but just beautiful and peaceful with lots of Japanese trees and flowers and bonsai. Some are also for sale. Very clean. There is a Japanese restaurant on the grounds where you can have lunch.If you have time don't miss it.

Not great. We haven been to Japan last year and I will not compare it to the wabi-sabi quality over there, but I have also visited Portland's Japanese Gardens which were way nicer. There were plastic bags in the pond, the grass was not cut well and not really a high diversity. It definetly lacks the Japanese refinements and for 50 pesos i expected a nicer kept garden..

Not a big fan. There are so many special, uniquely Argentine places to go in BA that I consider a visit here a wasit of time and money. It isn;t very big, and not very interesting. Go to Rosedahl down the road, for free, and see not only a gorgeous roase garden, but also portenos doing their thing.

Quiet & peaceful oasis; lovely gardens. Lovely Japanese gardens, though not particularly large. We visited for an opportunity to take a break from walking in the Recoleta neighborhood. Many benches provided the perfect place to rest. The restaurant serves only Japanese food, but there are a few carts serving ice cream and cold drinks. It seemed a bit pricey for the size of the gardens.

Very serene and calming. This was a part of a visit to the Botanical gardens. The care and maintenance of these Japanese gardens stand out and give the visitor a feeling for that country's skill in using Nature to create an atmosphere. The various walkways led to hidden delights. Well worth the effort.
Quiete and nice place. This is a nice and organized place. Quite interesting and beautiful to see! I just thought it could be a little bigger. Still is a nice place to see.

Great day and night.. Great park and is amazingly well kept. I think it is cleaner than most parks in Paris. The park has a 2-mile track around the outside and is full of locals running, roller-skating, walking, or riding bikes all day long. It is a prime spot to take a run anything during the day. Take a few hours to walk around and relax. Great island in the middle the city.

A little oasis. These historical gardens are well worth a look round if you're in this area of Buenos Aries. They are a delightful interlude, and close to the zoo, planetarium and other attractions. The entrance fee is only about £1.50.Recommended.

Small is beautiful. What a delight! The garden was introduced to us on a walking tour of the city and we just had to return. Whilst not large in area there is plenty to while away a peaceful hour in the midst of the bustling traffic. The lake is full of koi carp who obviously know that food is available to tourists to feed them with and there are several interesting monuments around the garden. The restaurant looked good but we did not have time to check it out for ourselves. An amazing collection of bonsai trees was available in the little nursery shop - what a shame we couldn't bring one home!

Great with young kids. Beautiful Japanese Gardens in downtown Buenos Aires.It is closeby the city center along the Libertador, next to Rosedal Park.It is worth the visit..My kids loved to feed the Huge fish in the ponds had a great time.Parking is a hassle as you have to park in the street so if you can go by taxi or better remis.
excellent. very nice , a place to visit when you are in Palermo, the restaurant with very sushi , the view from the restaurant is fantastic , you feel you are in Japan

A Beautiful Green space in the hustle bustle of a great city. Despite the fact that it wasn't free, the visit to this garden was a very pleasant one. Tranquility reigns supreme. And the simplicity of the space is not lost on us city dwellers. The grounds are well kept, clean of litter, and well manicured. And all the classic elements of a Japanese garden are there to bring serenity and joy.

Much better than Jardin Botanico. I thought these gardens were much prettier, better kept up than the Jardin Botanico a few blocks away. Of course, here you had to pay 50AR while the other was free. There is a little section of Bonsai plants for sale. I was a little disappointed there was no discussion of Japanese gardens symbolism/formatting in any language. Restaurant was closed for vacation but should be reopening shortly. BTW, we walked from our hotel. There were absolutely no signs showing he way to these gardens but we were easily able to ski/ get directions. Worth a 1 hour or so trip if you have time.

Nothing impressive. It is somehow nice, but nothing impressive. We have been there only because we were waiting the opening of Malba. Gardeners were working at the same time of the visit (this seems a bad management evidence for me) and the noise was quite disturbing.

Noisy Japanese selfie garden. S34°34.450' W°24.568' the tranquillity of this Japanese garden is totally overshadowed by the electronic shutter sounds of tourists and traffic and airplane noise. People visit to have their photos taken or with only virtual friends use a camera extension pole. The beauty of the garden is unimportant to them. Although beautiful sculptured with almost all iconic Japanese garden inventory, we could not find the Zen pebble garden, the public and the surrounding blocked any appreciation of the beauty of this garden in January 2015. The visiting Japanese Imperial family probably agreed. To admire the real thing fully and quietly, take an airplane to Kyoto. Entrance to the garden for foreign visitors is not free anymore: 32 pesos.

The most relaxing place. It was my third time in the Japanese Garden and it's still one of my favourite places in Buenos Aires. It's perfect for anyone who likes Japanese culture. It is beautifull and really relaxing. You can just enjoy the view drinking tea or having an ice cream. They always have some sort of exposition in the Garden too. My brother is a photographer and he took his best pictures there, so it's just the best place to admire the landscape, specially if you have a sunny day.

An oasis of calm in this bustling metropolis. Despite the presence of busy roads on two sides of the garden, there are plenty places where you can sit and take in the formal beauty of this wonderful garden. Centred around a small, rather murky lake, the meandering paths through the formal gardens open up new views at every turn. If you are visiting MALBA, take the time to visit this garden which is only a short walk away. There is a rather elegant restaurant in the garden and a tea house but there was not time on this visit to sample either.

Would be a 5 if better maintained. Beautiful garden for a walk, but it's not well maintained. There were two buildings that were boarded up and had someone's laundry hanging out to dry (?). There are so many plazas in buenos aires that this may not be worth it comparatively

Beautiful garden in the middle of a noisy avenue . The garden was nice, well organized but i could not feel a very quiet place as I expected from that kind of garden.If you are in the area and have some time is a nice place to visit to. The price was 32 pesos argentinos at the time that i was there.

Harmless, but free parks are better ....they're free!. Paid about £3 each to enter this small and disappointing park. What did we see - a dozen carp in a grubby pond, a japanese bridge in desperate need of a re-paint and a few dozen people wandering around trying to find what they had paid their money for. A safe haven from the crooks that spoil this city, but apart from that it was pointless.

A quiet refuge. Having spent a couple of days in the bustle of BA, it was nice to visit the gardens. Surrounded with traffic and activity, the area seems to drain the stress right out of you. It was nice to sit quietly on a bench and enjoy the Japanese vegetation and waters. It is a nice refuge, if you're wanting to take a break from the tourist pace.

Meh. I think my subject line summed it up but I need 100 words. It costs about 3-4 USD per person and it's very blah. I've been to a number of Japanese Gardens around the world and this one is sub par. The rose garden nearby is free and much nicer. Or just the public park next to it is nicer with large leafy trees and grass. So I would skip this place.

Small Japanese garden in the middle of BA. This garden is pretty small but well maintained. It's a good respite from the din of the city around it, though I wouldn't characterize it as a "must see" in BA. It's fairly small, a little uninteresting, and surrounded by much more interesting museums and sights. Although cheap (32 pesos pp) you can walk through it in about 15 minutes. If you're looking for a spot to sit and think or read a book then this is a good spot, otherwise I'd skip it. Also, the restaurant in the park is very tasty but horribly overpriced.

Great reflections on a sunny day. Japanese Garden was built by the Japanese embassy in the late 1960s.Nice stroll around ponds,gardens and the tea house.Options for food ,drink and souveniers.Cost is 40 pesos for adults and senior citizens are free.Taxi fare from city center(martin square) is 40 pesos each way.Time spent in the park will be between 40 minutes to an hour. Best pictures are from the north section of the park(skyline and garden reflection in the pond)The red reflections of the bridge are best photographed walking from the north point on the wooden bridge in the central pond.This park can be combined with the other nearby parks in the area.Nearby metro stop.
A calm oasis in a busy city. Lovely gardens to walk around on a sunny day. A truly peaceful and attractive environment close to the Museum of Latin American Arts.

One place to visit in Buenos Aires. The garden is very quiet, relax and peaceful, you see animals (ducks and very big fishes), trees, a peace bell and architectural beautiful. If you love the japanese food you can find a restaurant too.

Nice for a walk and a break from the noise. An unremarkable Japanese garden in the middle of a busy city. Its nicely groomed, yet not too interesting. A good place for taking a break from the noise and craziness of BAs streets.

Nice 1 Hour Stroll on a Sunny Day. Typical, albeit it small, beautiful Japanese garden within the city. It is a wonderful way to pass an hour walking around on a sunny day (again, very small, so I don't think you'd spend much more time than an hour here). Small admission fee along with small parking fee if you park on the street out front. Seniors are discounted, so show your ID. Grounds are in good condition and well kept. Overpriced, fancy restaurant on the grounds, small gift shop with low quality trinkets and small ice cream stands for a cool snack on a hot day. Not a must see for tourists, but an enjoyable stop nonetheless.

Oasis of Tranquillity. Beautiful gardens in the north-west of Buenos Aires. An oasis of tranquillity and a photographers delight. There is an admission charge but if you are a 'senior citizen' with documentary proof then it is free!
Can be skipped. Not that new or different from others that I have seen. Does not hold a candle to one in SF, ca. Not well kept up lots of dead and dieing plants.

Great place to relax. This is a beautiful place, a little quiet oasis in the middle of big city. We enjoyed walk around a little lake, flowers, bonsais, trees, statues, everything. The atmosphere was so calming that I even had a little nap on bench. Totally recommended!
a must!. absolutely adorable and a special place to spend a couple of hours, or more, relaxing and soaking in the beauty.

Nice place. Big and spacious, best time to go is by lunch time. The garden is full of Japanese trees and there is a big pond with enormous koi carps. Admission is 40 Argentinian pesos, which it's well worth it.

Peaceful. This was a beautiful and peaceful escape from frenetic Buenos Aires on more than one occasion. In addition to the classic Japanese gardens themselves, there's a very nice Japanese restaurant.
Bliss. The Japanese Garden offers a blissful retreat from the noise and traffic of .BA, where one can re-charge batteries. It also has a lovely restaurant.

Peaceful place. It´s my second time in beautiful Buenos Aires, and I had to come back to this beautiful japanese Garden, it´s a very beautiful place for you to recharge your batteries, take pictures, or just take a walk around. I love this place!
Do Not Eat Sushi Here. Gardens are nice to walk around and enjoy a beautiful day. The sushi restaurant is awful however. It was the worst sushi of my life, hands down.
Quite lovely. Not the biggest garden but very pretty with lots of features; very popular with locals and tourists allke. Looked beautiful in the sunshine. A lovely oasis in the big city!

Small Well designed Garden but nothing special.. I went to The Japanese Gardens with a group of friends on our way to MALBA museum which is nearby. We found an small Garden Well designed where you can relax and eat some sushi ( there is a restaurant inside).
Overall The Garden is nice but there are nothing special about it, nothing that could actually blow your mind.

Small, peaceful garden, a very relaxing spot!. We went here in August and there was not a lot blooming but the garden was still beautiful and tranquil. The garden is small- we were here less than a hour. The only thing to watch out for is the possibility of long lines to get in. We tried to go on a beautiful Monday afternoon that was a national holiday and the line to get in stretched around the block. We came back the next day and there were no lines. I don't if this was normal but something to keep in mind if you are thinking on going on a weekend or holiday.

A relaxing place to. Best to go in the summer/autumn in Buenos Aires.. We enjoyed a chilled walk around the Japanese garden. It was end of winter in August and so there were not many flowers blooming. The garden is kept well and there are some lovely features (the red bridge, a water-walkway and some nice routes). It takes less than 30 minutes to see. You can extend the visit by going to the adjoining restaurant with some very tasty Japanese specialities.

Beautiful gardens in central Buenos Aires. If possible choose a sunny day to visit. i was there with family from the United States on Sunday, it was a cloudy and windy day but everyone, specially the kids enjoyed the visit, watched the colored fishes and walked along the pathways and bridges. The place is very peaceful and quiet and on certain days there are special ceremonies, dances, drummers, sumo wrestlers. Entrance fee at the current exchange is less than 3 dollars.

Japan in Argentina. The Japanese Garden had all that could make it perfect: Cherry blossoms, a beautiful lake, a souvenir store... If you want to know your name in Japanese, check your luck or make a wish then, go there too. It was a bit crowded in the winter vacations, but there were no lines and we could walk freely and calmly. It is cheap to enter also.

Underwhelming. At one point this was supposedly the most impressive japanese garden outside of Japan- well not anymore! I do realize that BA has been in an economic crisis for quite some time, but what I saw here reminded me of my trip to China in '99. It tried hard to give the authentic vibe but it came off like a cheesy amusement park attraction and the ponds were filthy. There wasn't enough vegetation to give it an organic natural feel like a real Japanese garden and the use of asphalt walkways was an eyesore. I went to the Portland, OR Japanese Gardens the year before and that was amazing so you're definitely underwhelmed here. Since it was right by a bunch of major roads and is a relatively small place, you can't ever get out of your head you're in the middle of urban Buenos Aires in some run down faux Japanese Garden. The gift shop was also in poor taste- there was way too much anime and hello kitty and not enough traditional, classy gifts. They sold all these japanese junk food for kids such as melon ice pops and pocky but nothing truly authentic or worthwhile PS: no toilet paper in the bathrooms.

Nothing great about it. After visiting the malaba museum we went to the Japanese garden it was quite pricey , the entrance fee was 32 pesos per person and the garden though well maintained was not worth the entrance fee

A short lovely walk. We had some time to spare before leaving and we decided to pay a visit, since we love gardens. It is small but well kept. We were there in the morning so there were just a few people, and we had a nice stroll.

Beautiful!. The japanese gardens are within walking distance from Bosque de Palermo. The gardens are quite beautiful and well-kept. It has many ponds full of carps. There´s a japanese restaurant inside. The gardens are well mantained by japanese immigrants and their descendants who live in buenos aires.
Beautiful!. It is a nice place to escape the crazy hustle and bustle of the busy streets in BsAs. Beautiful and tranquil.

Peaceful. Nice manicured Japanese garden in Buenos Aires city. The fact that the park charges an entrance fee, makes it more exclusive and secure. There is not much to do apart from enjoying the scenery. Children and adults alike will enjoy the garden bridges and the friendly carp fish. The restaurant is usually crowded, so organize your visit to 'taste" this attraction in its full extension.

Beautiful Place to enjoy family time together. Beautiful setting. Ideal location for family outing away from city. Well laid out, bonsai trees, man made lake, greenhouse, rose garden, coyfishes and japanese resturant serving delicious meals.Nature at its very best.

Nice place to take pics!. This is a nice place to take pictures and to relax. Me and my wife really enjoyed the lake, where you can see really big carp fish! For those who like oriental/japoanese culture, this park is very amazing!!
Disconnect with the big city. The garden is really nice. It's small yet interesting. Beautiful place to take pictures and enjoy and pleasant time. Nice break from the outside world.

Wonderful Gardens. We love Japanese gardens. This garden first opened in 1967 and was donated by the Japanese community to the city twelve years later. It is one of the largest gardens of its type in the World, outside of Japan. It was a typical Japanese garden in that it featured manicured lawns, ponds full of large koi, streams flowing slowly over rocks, wonderfully pruned shrubs and small trees. It was not, however, peaceful, as it was bordered on three sides by busy, multi-lane roads and on the fourth side another park that sounded as though it was filled with dogs, their barking varied and continuous. We spent about ninety minutes strolling around the park and admiring its composition. Japanese gardens are very photogenic and I took many photographs.

Nice break in natural serenity. Went on a cloudy day and enjoyed our visit. Not very big, but great for an hour or two to disconnect with the outside world. Also included is a restaurant, cultural activities center, art, gift shop, coy breeding ponds. We enjoyed our visit very much, even on a rainy afternoon.

Only go if you have nothing else to do. Don't get me wrong, the garden is nice, but it's small and not really a must do or see. There are much better places for you to visit with you time in BA. If you've been to a japanese or chinese garden before, then don't bother going. Just more of the same.

Lovely afternoon walk. Excellent place to ease your mind in the last day of your trip. Good for couples and to take tons of pictures of beautiful flowers and gardens. Very well kept and secure. We tried to eat on the japanese restaurant as well but there was a waiting line (good feedback we heard from locals).

Relaxing place in the busy BA. Just to stroll around, feed the bird, take your shoes of and feel the grass between your toes, This park is just what you need if you want to escape the busy city for a few hours
Just Ok. Worth a brief look, but it isnt very big nor is it incredibly impressive. If you are in Palermo it is easy to get to.. so you might as well stop by.

Don't expect a Tokyo experience . but you're in BA, so what did you expect? If you haven't seen a true Japanese garden and you're already in the process of seeing the other nearby parks on a day trip (of which there are tons in walking diatance) then this is worth a stop, if nothing but for the chance to support the local Japanese community. Admission price is around 40 pesos per head but the restrooms are clean and you can relax without concern

Not worth a visit unless you are in the neighborhood. We visited the garden because other museums nearby were closed due to a holiday in Buenos Aires on our last day in town. We walked the path around the lake. I was disappointed overall, probably because I was comparing the garden to a recent visit to the Huntington Gardens in Pasadena, CA, which are outstanding.

Beautiful gardens. I really enjoyed the Japanese Gardens. We went to the Malba museum on the same day but you could also go to the botanical garden or zoo and all are very close by. Very small fee. I would advise going first thing in the morning (I think it opened at 10) as it was pretty busy then and only got busier.

Nice if you come in with low expectations. If you're looking for a nice, relaxing place to get away from the bustle of the city, I definitely recommend this. Just don't expect it to be an authentic Japanese garden. Also, there is saki in the gift shop. As of March 18, 2014, entrance fee was 32 pesos.
Pretty small but charming. The Japanese gardens are worth to visit.Very nicely arranged and everything is simple, natural but somehow also magical.A good place to spend an hour or two.

A joyouse escape to peace and quiet ..... wwwjardinjapones.org.ar. The Japanese garden can be reached in 15 minutes from town by taking a tube to Plaza Italia and walking about 1km .... or a bus from the city. It costs 32 Pesos (about two pounds Sterling) to gain entry and once inside peace and a lot of quiet reigns. The gardens are about 2-3 times the size of a soccer pitch and are laid out beautifully. There are bridges, lakes containing hundreds of huge Koi Carp, cafes, toilets, a shop by the entrance selling hundreds of plants for cheap prices and a rather pricey restaurant within the grounds. I went today and there were a few hundred visitors of all ages enjoying the atmosphere. Close by are the zoo, Botanical Gardens and the parks of Palermo ..... so spend the whole day in the area as it is a wonderful escape from the madness of Buenos Aires. The gardens are self-funding and receive no help and a most worthy of a visit.

Nice but noisy. Lots of parks to visit in Buenos Aires. This one you have to pay for (32 pesos). Not much but it all adds up! Was very well laid out but quite small and not the tranquility you would expect. A lot of road noise plus barking from the dogs being walked in the next door park.

Enjoyable walk, expensive lunch. The Japanese garden is a break from the hectic environment of Buenos Aires (BA) and is a very popular place visited by the BA and tourist individuals. For anyone over 65, the cost is zero and one is supposed to have ID to prove ones age. I suggest you do not carry your Passport with you, a driving license or some form of age proof will be needed. We had none, but still got in! We had lunch in the "Japanese restaurant" and as it was a Saturday, was crowded with lots of noisy children. I suggest you visit during the week once the children are back in school. The food was OK but it is not cheap. We spent approx. ARS$550.00 (USD approx. $55.00) for lunch for 2, Very expensive for BA.

Nice for a stroll... I you are in the area, but I would'nt go to Palermo just see the garden. It is very small and could use an upgrade!We combined the visit with the Zoo, MALBA, Botanic Garden and the Horse racing track. We had lunch (sushi) in the restaurant that is located in the Japanese Garden and it was very good - but quite expensive since I did'nt want the menues.

Average. Out of everything we saw in Buenos Aires, the Japanese Gardens were just okay. The teashop was a nice break from walking around Palermo and the food was decent, though a bit pricey. The gardens I found a bit small and not all that spectacular. If you have nothing else to do, I would go here but other than that, I would skip it and see some of the other attractions in the city.

Mintenance needs to be improved. I have been to many Japanese Gardens and this one definitely offers up some differences. Opened by the current Emperor and his wife many years ago, it is fairly large and reasonably well laid out, the only downside is the maintenance, it does not have the clean cut feel that I have come to expect of a Japanese Garden. The pebbles in the water have moss or mud all over them and the grass could have done with a good cut. Apart from this, nice location in the centre of the city but not sure it is a place I would go out of my way to walk to and sit down and contemplate the worlds issues.

Really beautiful. This is a great way to spend a few hours on a nice day. One of the nicest green spaces in a big city that I have ever seen. I really loved it and will definitely go back, if and when I go back to Buenos Aires.
Ok gardens considering the price. however it's nothing amazing, and pretty small. If you have 40 mins to kill, check it out otherwise feel free to skip.

A quiet haven in the center of a bustling city. We have visited many Japanese Gardens in cities across the globe. This one definitely meets the high standard that they have set everywhere else. The beauty and stateliness of the trees, bridges and sculptures create a backdrop of tranquility. Definitely visit if you need a respite from the crowds, shopping and noise of the city.
Very nice place for afternoons. Its a very calm and beautifull place to spend ur afternoons after a good meal elsewhere.Relaxing and full of greens to walk around and chill

An oasis in the city, but not that large. A retreat from the hustle and bustle of Buenos Aires. Well worth a visit if you are nearby, but not that big. More of a novelty than a pristine Japanese Garden. It is cheap and cheerful and deserves some support. A garden centre there too if you would like to buy some plants and shrubs.

Nice!. Lovely gardens and lakes in a nice setting amidst the 'green' area of the city. Some reviewers talk down these gardens but how much do you want out of a garden? Maybe they are not as immaculate as some Japanese gardens but in my view they are still of a high calibre complete with rose garden, pergolas, poets corner, quaint bridges & beautiful trees. A very relaxing tranquil all round setting!

OK garden; crummy restaurant. We ended up here on a Tuesday when the MALBA was closed, to our surprise. Ok for a visit, but not worth a trip. We tried the restaurant and had the worst Japanese meal ever. Seafood with grit in it, and chewy, unauthentic tempura. Avoid.

Unremarkable. As stated below this place is not much more than a small, Japanese-themed novelty garden. 24 pesos is not much to go in and see it (and get away from the streets for a bit), but the free parks nearby are a much better option in my opinion. I'm confident you could find better things to do with your time than visit this place.

Waste of Money- Stick to the Botanical Gardens. We ended up going to the Japanese gardens only because we were in BA for so long and almost ran out of things to do, but I wish we hadn't, it was a waste of money. There is nothing particularly remarkable or fun about the gardens. In fact, they're quite overrun with tourists and little kids, leaving no space to breathe or relax. There also isn't really a lot to see, they're rather small w/o much to see along the way. Particularly in light of the fact that these gardens are right next to the bigger, more beautiful and free botanical gardens, I would skip this.

Unremarkable. The Japanese Gardens are not too bad for enjoying a chill afternoon in a park, but then again, in that area there are many other parks which have equally enjoyable surroundings without the entrance fee of 24 pesos. I agree with Avi K on this one. I just visited Japan before coming to Bs As and don't really think this is representative of the lovely gardens there. Also the trees constantly dripped a slightly yellowish liquid... I would not go back..

Elegant small park to relax and beautiful photos. That was the first Japanese garden I have seen and I loved it. Beautiful setting around a pond. Different trees, a mini waterfall, beatiful trees, flowers and big big fish in the pond. If you would like to stroll in an elegant Japanese garden and take some memorable pictures, it is worth the entrance fee.

Admission?. The landsacping in Japonese gardens is usual precise immaculate and worthy of admiration and praise. This garden has a big pond with many large good fish, a bridge and a few trees around. The surroundings are pretty green as is everything in that area of Palermo. To charge 24 Peso admission, for what? The gift shop and restaurant are the most prominent features and add only to the commercial feeling of the place.Can easily be skipped.

Tranquil immersing setting that brings Kyoto to Buenos Aires. This calm tranquil garden in the midst of the hustle and bustle of Palermo is a good distraction and place to go just to get away from all the traditional flavours of Buenos Aires.The garden is rich in Japanese culture, down to the trees and fish.The restaurants also give provide rich a Japanese that is uncharacteristic of Buenos Aires.

Enjoyable and quiet place. I've been to this place several times. I like going here every time I go to Buenos Aires. It is a very peaceful place out of the hustle and bustle of the city.People usually go here to take nice pictures with all the typical japanese decorations. Last time I went was on last Saturday, and there was a Cosplay convention. It was fun to see lots of people wearing different costumes from manga, anime, video games and films. Most of them, of course, were Japanse characters.Something interesting to do in the Japanase Garden is to have your name written in Japanase. It's not expensive (USD 2) and it just takes a few minutes.Japanse Garden is very well-located in the Palermo neighborhood. Within a few blocks is the zoo, the planetarium, and the beatufil "Bosques de Palermo" (Palermo Woods) with plenty of activities to do there.

Tourist trap.. I'm amazed of how many people speak of the 'relaxing walks' in the garden or how this is a 'must-see'. But these people would probably also describe Disneyland as being 'authentic'.Seriously, this 'garden' has an entrance fee and once inside you'll be able to pose with hoards of tourists on japanese themed bridges etc. Every minute or so an airplane will pass over, adding more noise to the loud yattering already present in the park. Relaxing? No. Must-see? No.Avoid if you can.

A Japanese Corner in Palermo. This garden is one of the largest of its type in the world outside Japan. Opened in 1967 by the then Crown- Prince Akihito (present Japanese Emperor) and Princess Michiko and inaugurated on occasion of a State Visit.The entrance is on Figueroa Alcorta Avenue on the northeast corner of the city's extensive Parque Tres de Febrero. Many bus lines serve the place as Palermo (the area in which the Japanese Garden is located is a busy one).It has a cultural centre, restaurant, a greenhouse (well known for its collection of bonsai trees) and a gift shop (with an extensive selection of Asian garden seeds and craftwork).A brigde – known as Divine Bridge - crosses the Central Lake, representing entry into Heaven: The Truncated Bridge, in turn, leads to an island where Japanese medicinal herbs are grown.A Japanese Peace Bell, a large ishidoro (kind of stone lanterns of importance to Buddhist traditions), sculptures, a Buddhist Temple, flora from Japan, South America native species and carps can also be enjoyed. Everything contributes to the colourful atmosphere of the place. Japan’s traditional festivals are held here annually. The garden also includes a library with specialized volumes on Japanese issues, Cookery courses, Origami technique, Reading of Japanese Stories and Tales, and a free guided tour to the Zen Garden (on weekends). Last but not least: Acuatic landscape, kimonos and orchids expositions, and a bomsai clinic! Worthwhile. An oasis in the middle of the chaos! Relaxing! Would definitely go back!
A good place to relax. A small garden in the heart of Palermo. Feed the fish, relax, make a wish and enjoy this precious gift from the japanese people to the porteños.

Liked it.. Nice garden, but a little on the small side for me. The admission fee was on entering the garden. Plenty to see , felt nice here, I did like it. Great for the atmosphere and for the plants.

Cute little garden . . .. This garden is a cute place. We strolled through on a Saturday afternoon. There's an admission fee (I think around 30 pesos), and the whole garden relatively small. We took our time, and I think it was about a 45 minute walk. There were Japanese-type plantings, and the walk was situated around a pond with many carp. There were many families and couples strolling (with a great deal of picture taking). The garden is not spectacular, and, although it seemed relatively well kept compared to some of the other gardens, it wasn't immaculate and some of the walkways and bridges were in a bit of disrepair. We enjoyed this, and it was on our way between destinations, but I would not go out of my way to visit this if I wasn't in the area.
Very Like!!. Without words, this place is necessary go!!! For all the person go to Buenos Aires do not let go!!! The perfect place to take picturesa and relax!!

A VERY NICE CORNER. Argentina received an important Japanese colony, as other South American countries did, mostly during the XX century. Those immigrants and their descendants created this lovely environmental embassy of their remote homeland in the Palermo area, and take good care of it. Japanese shows are displayed here permanently.

Place to relax. This is a very peaceful place where you can sit down and relax for as long as you want. My advice is get there at the opening time which is ten in the morning if you want absolute peace. Later on more people start arriving. You can take really nice shots there.
japanese garden. quite boring as I went during winter, nothing much to see as none of the flowers are in bloom. there is a bridge over the pond which is a popular photo taking spot

Scenic, but small. The website claims that this is one of the largest Japanese Gardens outside of Japan....however, it appeared to be very small. I was able to walk the entire garden in less than 20 minutes. It won't be a disappointment if you miss it!

A jewel in the middle of the city. This is a remarkable garden in the heart of the city. The displays are beautiful and the kois are huge. There were activities or children as well. Certainly family friendly. We were there on a colder cloudy day and still enjoyed ourselves.

Not worth it - tourist trap. We visited the garden because of a recommendation in our guide book. It really wasn't worth the 24 pesos they charge for entrance. Any tranquility the place might have possessed was destroyed by traffic noise, obnoxious, brightly painted trash cans, too many "Don't tread on the grass" signs and exposed infrastructure. There were hoses spraying into the ponds and random tanks sort of sitting around. The enormous koi fish swimming around the pond were fun to look at for a minute, but overall it wasn't worth our money.

Great walk to relax. A nice peaceful place to walk and talk with a friend or a significant other. The only down side of this place is that they do not allow you to bring food to snack. They have a restaurant in the premises but we didn’t try it. It is about US$5.00 for entry fee.

Beautiful gardens, good restaurant. We really enjoyed our visit to the Japanese Garden. We had a leisurely sushi lunch - very good - followed by a relaxing walk through the gardens. Close to the zoo which is also worth a visit.

Come for the gardens, stay away from the restaurant. My wife and I had some higher expectations of a japanese restaurant, located in a japanese garden. It looked like a Japanese restaurant, sounded like a Japanese restaurant, then we saw the menu... And it was all down hill from there. First off, the selection of maki available makes a California roll look legit. Every single option either has cream cheese or f'ing cheddar cheese. That's just sad. The noodle dishes had what looked like spaghetti. In the end we ordered a few things that seemed palatable. First were the salmon dumplings... These are more like deep fried salmon wantons... They arrived a little burned on the outside, and still frozen on the inside. Not cold, frozen. So we sent it back (and we never send back food) to warm it up. 5 minutes later, comes back... Still frozen on the inside. Embarrassing. Third time was a charm, and it ended up being an ok appetizer. In no way authentic, but passable.I ordered the tuna tataki. One of my favorite dishes, and listed as a speciality. Which they came back to tell me they didn't have any. Sad. Ordered some nigri in it's place. My sunomono salad was a pile of cold noodles and cucumber. Almost no seaweed, and barely any kani at all, I guess less than one piece of kani all told. It was tasty for what it was, but it wasn't a sunomono salad. My wife ordered the swordfish. This was delivered to the wrong table, where that patron mistook as his meal, and put his fork into the accompanying salad. The fork he had already used. The server noticed the mistake... But just moved it to our table. More fantastic service. The swordfish itself was decent, but could have used a little flavour enhancement. The highlight of the meal was my nigri. The fish was very fresh and delicious. This is what to order, even if the selection of nigri is very limited.When we were done our meal, it took 2 requests to get the bill,and about 15 minutes in total. Thank you for wasting our time. This was only the second time in my life I didn't leave a tip. Service this bad is an embarrassment, and would not be tolerated in any real japanese restaurant.

Not worth it. First, you have to pay 24 pesos just to get in the garden. There they'll show you a map that's totally out of scale (they try to make the garden look bigger than it actually is). The visit will be over in minutes, unless you're willing to buy some overpriced souvenir in their shop. This is the only Place in Buenos Aires I totally regret having lost my time visiting.

Visit if you have time. Not a must see.. Recently I visited the Japanese Garden in Buenos Aires. While it is rather inexpensive there is not a whole lot to do there. The garden itself is very nice. It gives you a feeling that you are not in a giant city. It only takes maybe 30-45 minutes to walk through the entire garden. If you are looking for something to do and you are in the area I would stop by. I wouldn't make it a must see if you are in Buenos Aires

No Must-See at all!. We were very keen on seeing the japanese garden. However, we were quite disappointed.First, its not very big. So you cross the garden in very few time. As streets are surrounding the garden, you can hear the noise of the city constantly in every part of the garden.Second, if you have been in Japan: this is far away from an amazing "true" japanese gardenThird: you have to pay entrance fee, whereas in the other Palermo Gardens you dont have to pay for entrance, like for example in the Parque Rosedal (Which is far more attractive).Fourth: Its very "touristy": "Pay Entrance, buy a bonsai, go to the restaurant"..Therefore: we suggest to walk through the other parks without paying entrance. you still have nature and less noise than here...

Don't worry if you miss this. Rather bland Japanese garden if you have seen gardens in Japan (or elsewhere in the world). Lousy design. Surrounded on all sides with roaring traffic, so there is no chance for peace and/or contemplation. It completely misses the soul that a true Japanese garden has.

Don't worry if you miss this. Rather bland Japanese garden if you have seen gardens in Japan. Lousy design. Surrounded on all sides with roaring traffic, so there is no chance for peace and/or contemplation.

an oasis in one of the top 20 cities. Buenos Aires has roughly 13 million people, and it's a busy, hustling place almost everywhere you go. But an hour in these gardens is a great restorative. Bonzai for sale, a nice little food shop and even a sushi restaurant are located on the edges of the garden and don't get in the way of the peace and serenity of the ponds and small waterfalls and red lacquer bridges. I found no nicer place to relax in Buenos Aires. Clean, safe, beautiful and intricate and thoughtful.
Beautiful but not so great for a paid garden. This japanese garden is well taken care of, and its have a lot of things to take pictures of/with but that is about it.

Nice but small. Worth it if you're in the area.. Don't bother making a special trip here, but if you're in the area, it's not bad. It wasn't too crowded when we went, but it as rather hot and still early in the morning. I'd imagine that the crowds got bigger as the day went on.

Nice japanese garden. Calm beautiful place for a walk.Families with children seen to like the place. Not my case. It was just me and my wife.If you are going on foot from the south, you should go by the President Figueroa Alcorta Avenue, really nice views and nice gardens all along the way.

better on a weekday. only worth it to eat lunch in the resto!. If you've never been to a Japanese garden, then it will be magical. If you go on a weekday, it will be peaceful. If you go on a sunny weekend, then you will instead critically note that you have paid for the experience of looking at trash-littered walkways, dying patches of grass, obese fish with festering sores on their scales, dirty pond water, and hearing the clamor of children begging for more pesos to buy more fish food, thus disturbing whatever Zen moment you were hoping to have strolling in the gardens park.Towards the back is an authentic Japanese restaurant that only serves lunch. Make reservations and hide out there, away from the crowds.
Worth a Walk. It is a very charming garden, a good diversion for about an hour or so. I never have seen so many dragonflies in one place.

If you've never seen a Japanese garden, maybe it's worth it. Otherwise not.. We expected to pay an admission of US $4-5 and were pleasantly surprised to find that this attraction is free for people over 65 (with document of proof of age). This is good, because as something free we didn't mind it. If we'd needed to pay, I'd be complaining. If you've been to the Japanese gardens in Rockford Illinois or the Pacific Northwest of the US you'll find this a real disappointment. Very little is special, and the water is so clouly any fish aren't visible. But it's a nice, tranquil place in the middle of the city, with plentiful benches, so it's worth it for that. And for the intercultural exchange and interest that it represents.
Relaxing atmosphere. Although I went in the winter and it was rather cold, the manicured gardens, the streams ,little lakes and small bridges, the tranquility it inspires, really paid the visit.
Beutiful garden to relax. It is a nice typical japanese garden. It is small but you can sit and read. A space to relax in the middle of the city. There were some kids having fun.

Worth it esp for kids. Since this is one of the larger ones in the world, really wanted to go to it. Its lovely, has a lot of water features and bridges, different elevations, and a great nursery in the back. It can be hot in early January so have hat or umbrella. You can eat at a cafe/cafateria there. LOTS of kids, they love feeding the KOI. It was amazing seeing them -a lot like a photo I have seen = frenzy of color.As others have mentioned, there are others that have more features- one outside of San Jose in California comes to mind, where you can actually visit a japanese tea house. This has a tea house, but seems was not open, being repaired, not entirely sure.

Serene respite. These gardens aren't going to blow your sox off but if you're sick of humanity and want a quiet reprieve, the 8 peso entry fee is enough to keep crowds down (unless you have the misfortune of arriving when a school trip is visiting). As other reviewers have said, these grounds don't compare to a real japanese garden but there are carp in the water and a few bridges and bonsai trees strategically placed. I've had green tea at the community center/restaurant and I can attest to the authenticity of the azuki bean paste tea biscuits! yummy!

I couldn't get in!. I'm not exactly sure what went on at the ticket booth at the Japanese Gardens, but I didn't get in! The lady in the ticket booth said something to me in Spanish that I didn't understand and beckoned me to stand to one side. I thought maybe she didn't have change for my 100 peso note and so waited a bit, but with the number of people buying tickets before and after me, it couldn't have been the case and so I wandered off very confused. Later on, I told a few locals about the scenario and none of them could explain what it was about. Anyway, I'm sure the gardens are very nice - if you are allowed in!

Go to Japan instead. Well, everything looks neat and nice. But it's far from a genuine Japanese garden. Don't go here if you don't have lots of time over, or never have been to any Japanese gardens in your life and you know for sure that you'll never go to Japan. Otherwise, spend your time somewhere else, or go to Kyoto :)
Fresh air. Enjoyed a walk around this well maintained garden ...and the chance to get some fresh air after the diesel bus fumes in the city centre
A quiet retreat. you can almost forget there's a busy city with wide boulevards congested with traffic outside. avoid the overly expensive restaurant and then make your way to the rose garden nearby.

Not impressed. The garden is OK but I don't think it was worth the visit. There are much better gardens all over the world. The place is kept clean but it is fairly small and doesn't have any memorable attractions. It is also a bit out of the city center.

below average garden. We have been to a lot of japanese gardens so perheps we are a bit biased. If you have never been to one, then you should check it out. If you have had that experience before this will be underwhelming.

perfect small relaxation spot. we love this garden, it is on a smaller side but oh so peaceful, tranquil. Our kids like to go there to feed fish, I like to relax and admire beauty. There also is a a restaurant but food is so so. The entrance is really inexpensive and all kids under 12 are free.

Just okay.. This Japanese garden was just okay, it was probably a 20 minute stroll all the way around. When we went it was absolutely packed so it was hard to see all the attractions. We actually traveled to Japan and were very impressed by authentic Japanese gardens but this lacked certain character and wasn't too well maintained. The water was dirty and we couldn't see any koi fish, other than the occasional one that would come up really close to the surface. I was actually surprised to learn that this is the biggest Japanese garden in the world outside of Japan., didn't seem like it. I think there are a lot better things to do in Buenos Aires!

Not impeccably maintained nor perfectly traditional. This was ok for a 15 minute stroll but the gardens need more maintenance (dirty water, grass full of weeds) and it's not free (unlike the nearby rose gardens). We enjoyed a special bonsai exhibition and the restaurant was packed but the garden itself was just ok.

Serene & peaceful. Not sure why other reviews are saying its not worth visiting. It's really green, serene and beautiful. There were lots of people but it was still enjoyable, and parts of the garden were very peaceful, with running streams etc. Was a nice change from the hustle and bustle of the city. The red bridge especially looks like postcard like in my pictures. 16 pesos is nothing for the entrance fee once converted in GB pound (£2.30).

Not very authentic. Having been lucky enough to visit actual Japanese Gardens in Japan this felt very commercialized and not at all authentic. It was 16 pesos each to get in and although the gardens were pristine it all felt manufactured rather than natural. The big lake was very dirty so it was difficult to properly see the enormous Koi Carp - many of whom looked the worse for wear from sores or fungi. We took a picnic which saved on the quite expensive fast food available from the kiosk. What was interesting was a display of aquariums designed with bonsai tree type underwater plants and the garden shop which was selling normal bonsais in their own right. It is very popular with tourists & locals. The amount of people there when we went was overwhelming and not at all conducive to a feeling of peace

Not worth a visit. This is a very unusual "thing to do" in BA. I am not sure why people would want to visit here when there are much nicer parks in BA, and it doesnt even feel Japanese. Not worthy of the entrance fee, especially when you can do the entire loop in 5 minutes.

Ummmm....why?. Not sure why this is ranked so highly as a sight worth seeing in BA, it is a nice garden with Japanese influence, not sure it's a must do for anyone visiting Argentina. You're better off saving the entrance fee for paying someone to clean off all the dog doo from your shoes from walking the streets of BA (which is far more interesting than checking out well kept Japanese gardens).

Great place to rest in the middle of the city caos. Worth the visit! Buy the origami bird, write down your wishes and hang on the big wall to bring you good luck! Take a minute to seat and rest watching the gardens and the big lake . 16 pesos the entrance. Highly recomend!

Nice place in the center of the city. A good place to walk a little bit, eat some japanese food and enjoy the beautiful flower species of the greenhouse (specially the orchids, the place also gives monthly talks and seminars on how to cultivate these kind of exotic flowers)

Stunning. I think this garden was lovely. The coy were large and plentiful. Three touches that I really like we're the lanterns, statues, and red bridge. For your own pleasure, I liked this more than the Amazon, sure it's nice to be able to say you've been to the amazon, but it isn't really super beautiful or peaceful. But the thing I thought was the best was the placement, everything seemed to be in the perfect place. If you ever go to Buenos Aires, or even city neighboring Buenos Aires, I highly suggest you go there.

Interesting switch from "normal" Buenos Aires scenery. Beautifully well laid out and kept location. We went on a cold sunny day and the clear blue sky really combined well with the Red Japanese Bridge, lake, orange fish and all.

Nice respite from the city!. Most definitely a lovely garden and a nice respite from the hecticness that is Buenos Aires (but we all love this city, no?). Had a lovely bridge, and a koi pond with the largest koi I have ever seen in my life! We walked all the trails because it is a fairly small space, but don't let that deter your visit, it was still lovely. There is a botanical garden/nursery (of sorts I suppose, you can also buy plants there as well) that is worth a stroll through as well!! If youi want some tea, or maybe sushi, there is a restaurant on the property, although we didn't go in so we can't comment on price or quality.
Relaxing. Odd that i should like this in Argentina, but so relaxing and sometimes there are events in the gardens or halls.

Too crowded. Nice place, when I went you had to pay only $2. It was pretty, you could see all kinds of flowers and they had asian theme shows. I went on a Sunday and it was too crowded.. that was the only downside.

Nice garden but could use maintenance. It has a nice feel for Japan and the koi pond was great. But it was smaller than expected and getting a bit run down.
I liked it though I didn't think it was exceptional.
Small but a representaion of Japan. A pleasant park to walk about giving a hint of what a Japanese gardens are all about. Worth a visit

A true japanese space in middle of capital federal. I come here allways I can, to spend some hours viewing not only trees and fishes, but also their culture, their typical garden distribution, their cook, and their manners. It's beautiful.

Very pleasant place to spend the afternoon. We paid a visit to the place on June 07 and we simply loved the place. It's got wonderful well-cut and maintained gardens, looking like an oasis in the middle of the bursting and vibrant Buenos Aires atmosphere. We also ended up getting a late afternoon tea and some desserts at the very good Tea House located inside at the back of the garden. Just be aware that one has to pay for the entrance (equivalent of USD 10 per person), but it's really worth it. In case you need to get a cab back to your place/hotel, just upon exiting and turning right you'll find an avenue where you can get one easily.There's also a place to have free origami courses, if you like it. Recommended!
If you have time. The Japenese Garden is interesting. It is not very big but it is beautiful. They have koi fish in their ponds and my friends and I had fun taking pictures.
Beautiful gardens in the middle of the city. Wonderful gardens to stroll through. Lovely display of local flowers.

Wonderful little park. As others have mentioned this is a wonderful little park in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Buenos Aires. I did notice the air traffic some, but the car traffic noise was somthing that I did not seem to notice, probably because I was fascinated with the beauty of the garden. The garden has all of the traditions of a typical Japanese garden. We visited in their fall and while many things were not in bloom, it was still beautiful and relaxing. It is not a huge park but a good enough size to get away for awhile. It was a beautiful sunny day when we were there and there were quite a few people visiting the park. We had a very late lunch in the restaurant at the park. It was superb. Great service, wonderful food topped off with an exquisite Argentine white wine. If you like Japanese food/sushi, you should give the place a try. I don't think you will be disappointed. We weren't.

Not quite tranquil. Shame about the airport being so close by, and being surrounded by busy roads. Potentially could be a very relaxing haven if it weren't for the noise. Nice to walk through (but costs $16 pesos) and it does represent Japanese gardens well, but I'd only go here if you had time to fill in.

Beautiful oasis in the middle of Buenos Aires. Who knew Buenos Aires held such a lovely garden in the middle of the city? We really enjoyed visiting this though it would have been much prettier in the spring when all the azaleas would have been blossoming. Don't miss their restaurant!

It's beautiful. It's a garden. It's japonese.. What to expect to a place like this? It's beautiful. It's a garden. It's japonese. And it's clean, quiet and peaceful, great for couples and children. But that's it. It's not expensive - around 16 pesos per person - but I really think Rosendal and all the green area around Recoleta is more worth. If you don't have a Japanese Garden in your city, you should go. In 30 minutes, you're done. If you have already visited one Japanese Garden, think twice.
BEAUTIFUL PLACE TO SPEND A FEW HOURS. Stroll through this beautiful garden, feed the Koi, or just sit and read a book. This is a serene venue to spend a few hours.

Only if you have time to kill. I was pretty underwhelmed and would not recommend unless you have nothing else to do. We ate at the restaurant and while the food was excellent with great presentation, I found it expensive and the portions were tiny. My partner and I always share an appetizer, main meal and dessert. We were starving so we ordered two appetizers along with the main meal. It was my understanding that the meal came with rice but it did not. It took forever to get our food, we were still hungry when we were done and chose not to order dessert because we had already lost so much time.

Not worth a visit. Its nice and everything but you are visiting Buenos Aires, not Japan, so I wouldn't waste my time going to the Japanese Garden when you can visit places with a real latin and "porteño" feeling.

Very small and not much to see - a bit underwhelming but at least clean. The redeeming factor of this park (and therefore my 3 stars and not less) is the very low entry price of 16 pesos per person. You don't expect much for this kind of money in Buenos Aires, and that's exactly what you get - not much. The park is very small, has a lake with lots of carp, a couple of Japanese walking bridges, and ... well, that's pretty much it. You would have to be a very strong admirer of Japanese garden design to see anything else. If you're in the area, you might want to give it a shot, but really only if you have nothing else to do.

Service was friendly food was good although portions were tiny. Great settingFood was good although the portions were tinyThe waitress in the beginning was incredibly attentive but then she forgot about us.The tea was delicious
A oasis of calm!. A nice change from the busy streets - beautifully maintained and worth spending time there. Don't miss the restaurant!
A fun afternoon.. The restaurant is yummy, the park is lovely, but a lot of traffic noise.

Nothing.. Ok, the tourism publicity says it is the bigger japanese garden of the world, an incredible place ....First of all, it's Ar$16, one of the most expensive atractions of this kind in Buenos Aires. Inside, there is a big lake, with two bridges and some shrubs pruned in oriental style. The water is dirty, with some garbage floating. There is a japanese house, with 4 kimonos, maybe the unique really interesting thing of the place. It's nothing excepcional, compared to the other gardens and lakes of Palermo. And after all, you can see similar places in any part of the world. It's better to use your time with other atractions, go there just if you really have time and already visited the mainly atractions of the city.

I picture it bigger. Its pretty, but too small. Is just like you see it in pictures. Got to pay 16 pesos, around 4 $ for a 15 minutes walk in a park. Yet is ok if you go with your girlfriend or boyfriend

A little of Japan in Buenos Aires. It´s a cute place in Buenos Aires that looks just like Japan, though during weekends can be a little overcrowed. If you´re around and willing to rest for a while, go inside, chill out and enjoy some tea!

An oasis in the middle of the city. Amazing place just in the middle of the city. Very chip ticket. Bring a book and find your spot to relax.
They also have a very good tea house, although it has become very expensive.
They also have a bonsai and plants selling area, with has also increased its prices considerably.
Beautiful. Beautiful location, very well kept and organized. Worth the visit.
A clean area to walk around. This is a very clean area to take in some quiet in the middle of Buenos Aires. There is admission but that's what keeps it maintained I suppose.
A Place of Tranquility. A place to take a pleasant quiet stroll in beautiful surroundings amidst the hustle and bustle of Buenos Aires.

Beautiful and crownded. The jardin is wonderful and quite good conserved. I went on Sunday, when it was hosting a Anime/Manga event. I enjoyed it a lot seen so many youngs dressed in costumers. The event was attraction by it self, if you don't mind this kind of event.

Worth the visit. A very pleasant and quiet garden, as you would expect , in typical Japanese style, with bridges and koi ponds. This is a good contrast with busy Buenos Aires, and certainly well worth the visit.
Be aware there is an entrance fee, and it can get pretty crowded at peak times on weekends.
Nice for a little break. It takes a while to go there if you walk but, even on a sunny afternoon, it's worth a visit. Nothing impressive really... But Nice !

Wonderful Gardens in heart of city. Our son and his wife joined us on a visit to these gardens in a beautiful setting in Recoleta this past week (January 31st, 2012). The entrance fee was around $3.50 per person and was worth it. The gardens and ponds were excellent in many ways. The koi were huge and entertaining; the bonzai trees were lovely; and the overall experience was four-star. It helped that the day was bright and not so hot. It looked like most people were pleased and glad that they had made the time to spend some time here.
