Beautiful place.. A beautiful well maintained garden in the middle of a large city. It may be small, but it is well worth the visit. Plenty of good photo ops.
Small but cute. Well maintained compared to public parks; small but attractive layout; restaurant not open until February 1, 2012. Try the melon ice cream bars, refreshing!
Didn't like to pay. It's a public space, but you have to pay to get in. Very charming, indeed. But we couldn't spend more than half an hour there.

An bit of peace in the middle of the city. Bring a good book, sit under a tree and enjoy the peace.Or you could explore with friends and take some of the interesting activities offered almost everyday. I took a massage called Shiatsu, completely for free, but you also have martial arts exhibitions, origami lessons and a lot more. They change everyday, so I recommend checking the schedule first.Children love to feed the koi fish under the bridges (I've seen it's addictive on most of them), so they'll be having fun too.It's a small place, so if you walk straight through it shouldn't take more than one hour. But between pictures, activities and some sushi at the restaurant, you'll end up being three hours.
A little disappointing. 16 peso and not really worth the money.Very small place, not that pretty and nor very interesting.
Lovely. You can combine it with the Rosedal and visit 2 lovely landscaped parks.
Tranquility in the Busy City. This is a wonderful, 2-hour activity that will help the visitor to find peace and tranquility in the city. The entrance price is very inexpensive.

Nice place to hang out. It's a beautiful place to spend time with your family feeding the fish and enjoying the view, totally recommend it to turists who enjoy taking photos (you can take great pictures there).

Beautiful and peaceful park. Perfect way to escape the noises of the big city. I went there houndreds of times and of course it is better to go on week days, since the weekend its pretty crowed. If you like exotic plants or taking colorful photographs, this is your place!

Beautiful place to chill out. Seems strange to recommend a Japanese Garden in the middle of BA - but it's absolutely genuine, a gift from the people of Japan, and very beautiful. It is a complete haven of tranquility away from the bustle of the city. All the other visitors seemed relaxed, too, it wasn't just us! And the food in the very authentic restaurant is good, and reasonably priced, certainly by London standards. If you want to take a break from the city, I'd recommend getting here about 11, an hour or so walking the garden, then lunch.
Nice break in the city. it's a nice park to take pictures and walk around. set in the middle of the palermo parks it's good for children and adults
great. beautiful, good place to take family, girlfriend. etc

Touristy but pretty. The Japanese Gardens in Palermo are a nice place to take pretty pictures. There is an entrance fee of $8 pesos. It's not very big, but it's tranquil and there are nice spots to take pictures of the pond and bridges. There is a concession stand where they sell snacks and drinks near the entrance. Also, there is a restaurant inside the garden that sells Japanese food. I'm not sure how the food is but the prices seem to be average. Mostly there are a lot of tourists here taking a LOT of pictures..
A nice touristic place. The japanese garden is a nice a well built place in the hectic city of Buenos aires.We enjoyed visiting there for 2 hours, and take a break from the concrete surround us.

Beautiful Place. Its a very beautiful garden near of the Bosques de Palermo. The area is covered with tipical japanese vegetation, rocks and a bridge were you can take several photos. Inside the garden there is a good japanese restaurant. It's a good place to spend the afternoon.
Peaceful and beautiful. Very nice place to spend the morning. It's very peaceful and beautiful. Enjoy their restaurant too, with very good food.
Peaceful garden. This garden had lots of nice plants, huge koi, and great sculptures. I really enjoyed the bridges and looking at the birds.
A beautiful Garden. A beautiful garden with lots of colour. Rhododendrons were stunning. Well thought out.Had a nice coffee and Japanese biscuit in the restaurant.

Relaxing little place. Nice little relaxing Japanese style garden in the middle of the city, it has plenty of ponds, bridges, boardwalks, and sculptures, great place to visit to take pictures of the scenery and feed the fishes at the ponds or to have a nice meal at the restaurant with your couple. It has a few souvenirs shops where you can buy traditional gifts, or even get your name translated in Japanese.You could see the whole park in less than an hour, I definitively would recommend visiting this attraction along with the Buenos Aires Zoo which is really close by, you could see both things easily in half a day.
Cute and small. Only go if you have time to spare. Gardens are maintained but need a few more places to sit and contemplate.
Nice!. Small, peaceful park. Use to be part of President Rosa land. Fun to feed the fish.
beautiful place. I really liked this garden . It is small , cute , and the restaurant was nice , too. Good place for some photo shots.
Not very interesting. These Japanese gardens are ok but not very special. That also goes for the Japanese food in the restaurant.

Not so great. Parque 3 de Febrero is time better spent. I had hoped for more, having seen the beautiful Japanese garden in Portland, Oregon. However, the one in Buenos Argentina has little to offer. But for 8 pesos, what does one expect? The flower show that happened to occur when we visited displayed some stunning varieties. The signs everywhere telling visitors not do climb rocks, touch the fish, or walk on the grass became a source of amusement, and they detract from what peaceful beauty one might try to conjure. If you are short on time, go next door to Parque 3 de Febrero. The rose garden and lake are pretty. The people watching (as they jog, walk, roller blade and bicycle around the lake) is great. The museum had some good art when we were there, and, it's free.

Beautiful and relaxing. I liked the Japanese Garden quite a lot. It's a great way to get some sun, take a peaceful stroll, and relax in the big city. The pond contains tons of koi.As in any other park in Buenos Aires, you will see young people kissing everywhere. This kind of happiness is wonderful to see. Act like a local and kiss your loved ones in public on a bench in the gardens!Be sure to stop at the "Oraculo de la Suerte" - oracle of luck - and leave behind a note for whatever you're seeking. The sign says that you can purchase the papers at the Casa de Artesan.My friend and I were lucky, there was a special event for the Manga & Anime festival, so many locals were at the park in all sorts of interesting costumes. This event happens twice per year.When we visited, it was 8 pesos per person.

If you don't have a lot of time - skip it. The park is nearby the MALBA art museum. On the way there you get to walk through some large parks but watch out, this is favorite stomping grounds for the dog walkers. Oddly, they prohibit photography but if you ask, they will give you a "press pass" to wear and you can take photos. Once inside, I saw nobody with a photo pass so I don't think this is enforced. It was a nice stop - but if you are short on time, skip this attraction.
Relaxation and quiet from the city, a must walk. Spend an hour to chill from the noise of the city. Walk to malba museum and enjoy the art.
Amazing. I appreciated this visit a lot for many reasons: I could enjoy the landscape, meet tne ancient culture, discover the Koi fishes. I loved the Bonsais. Wonderful place!!! Beautiful souveniers.

Nice and interesting.. We enjoyed our visit. There was a lot of maintenance by the garden crew in the morning. We went on a weekday for 8 pesos a person. Took some photos and had a few drinks at the outside snack shop. Not exactly an Argentine experience but a nice little venture if you are nearby.

Restaurant gets a ZERO, garden gets a 10++. Restaurant is total garbage. AVOID. Tried to order a beverage and bite, waitresses were busy gossiping. Food, well never saw any, after 30 minutes, had to leave. Garden, beautiful. Second trip to BA and the garden was the most delightful in the city. A must see attraction. Admission was 8 pesos and well worth it.

Only if you're in the area and have got time to kill. I thought these gardens were quite ordinary (and small). If you're in the area and have got time to kill you might want to go in and have a look but otherwise I wouldn't make an effort to get to them.

Worth a visit if in the area. We enjoyed our brief visit here. Although the entrance fee is currently 8 pesos per person at weekends. It doesn't quite match some of the gardens you may find in Tokyo and the traffic roaring around the edges doesn't help the atmosphere tremendously. But the pretty pathways and ponds make for a pleasant stroll.

Peace and Beauty garden in a metropolis. Going to Buenos Aires, make you think about Tango, bookstores, soccer, but you can have a time for the simple beauty of a Japanese Garden.Filled with beautiful paths within ponds with carps, pine trees and Japanese-style ornamentation, it's a jewel of tranquility inside the stress of a big city. The Japanese garden is worthy to go, principally after walking around inside the Zoo - the other side of the street. The most beautiful photos of BA were taken there.There's a fine Japanese restaurant inside, with a fair service and magnificent view of the garden.

Nice but definitely not the best I've seen.. Nice diversion if you have a week or so in BA. I thought the garden was small and off the beaten path. It was well maintained but the Restaurant was closed the day we went. No real exotic plants. If you just want to relax this may be for you but I found it quite boring. It only takes about 45 minutes to see everything.

relaxing and peaceful, good Japanese restaurant on premises. If you are in the area, definitely stop by. Unlike other attractions in BA, this is not free, but the admission was very modest (less than $2 I believe). There are koi and you can buy food for them. The gardens are not big, but very pleasant, with birds drinking from water fountains, koi begging for food, pleasant flora, bridges, and a waterfall. We had a great sushi lunch and the cafe in the garden. The food was fresh and tasty, and the prices were reasonable. Don't miss the tuna dumplings appetizer -- super delicious!

Quiet & Peaceful urban insert. The Japanese Gardens offer a great city escape right in the hub of Buenos Aires. There is a small admission fee, which includes an un-timed visit in the gardens and access to the restaurant. The plants, sculptures and scenery is beautiful and truly a great for a city getaway, right there in the city.

Second Largest Outside Japan...Lovely!. The entrance fee is $5 pesos (approx. $2.50 dollars)...It's so calm and beautiful in this place...Lovely little lakes filled with Koi fish...And the landscaping is just gorgeous...Well worth the inexpensive entrance fee....I loved it...

A cute little oasis in the middle of the city. The Jardín Japonés was very sweet - lovely to look at and a nice little wander, or a bit of a bask in the sunshine. However - don't come in the week - there are lots of groups of school children who just spoil the tranquility with all their shouting. Its best on a weekend.
